The term takes as its point of departure Judith Butler’s insight that gender is a socially constructed system of norms that must be constantly performed and prescriptively regulated to maintain its illusion of stability - a</p> <blockquote> repeated stylization of the body, a set of repeated acts within a highly rigid regulatory frame that congeal over time to produce the appearance of substance<<cite "33" "Butler, Judith. Gender Trouble.">>. </blockquote> <p>However, this contemporary moment, where ‘embodiment’ is dematerialized to an unprecedented extent, warrants a close consideration of what ‘bodies’ are stylized to produce the appearance of a gendered substance. Considering masculinity from a multimedial perspective means doing just this: thinking about the different platforms, like social media, through and on which social gestures are performed.</p> <p>Multimedia masculinity, then, is a way of thinking about masculinity as it is performed through the bodies electric: in Facebook posts and tweets, on MMOs and Slack servers. Gender in this mode of thinking becomes something akin to <<define "genre">>; as Lauren Berlant puts it:</p> <blockquote> To call an identity like a sexual identity a genre is to think about it as something repeated, detailed, and stretched while retaining its intelligibility, its capacity to remain readable or audible across the field of all its variations <<cite "4" "Berlant, Lauren. The Female Complaint.">> </blockquote> <p><<define "Medium" "medium">> - or platform - vary, and inflect both gender and genre, so the kinds of masculinity that these different media make possible - and prevent - are necessarily inflected by the generic tropes and traits of the platform in question. This, then, is a rearticulation of my broader argument about <<define "informativity," "information and selfhood">> or of performance and selfhood on digital platforms.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 5">><</silently>><p>A good point of entry for considering masculinity in Achewood is the 2006 arc “The Great Outdoor Fight,” which was the first story arc published in hardcover, by Dark Horse Press in 2008. <i>The Great Outdoor Fight</i> tracks Ray and Roast Beef as they compete in - and ultimately win - the eponymous fight.</p> <p>The Fight is an excellent case study for the performance of masculinity because it is a "homosocial enactment" in exactly the way Michael Kimmel writes about:</p> <blockquote> We test ourselves, perform heroic feats, take enormous risks, all because we want other men to grant us our manhood. Masculinity as a homosocial enactment is fraught with danger, with the risk of failure, and with intense relentless competition. <<cite "33" "Kimmel, Michael. The Gender of Desire.">> </blockquote> <p>For Kimmel, men become men when they are recognized as such by other men, and the structure and ritual of competition is a pretext for precisely this mode of enactment.</p> <blockquote> Three days! Three acres! Three THOUSAND men! Only one will win THE GREAT OUTDOOR FIGHT! </blockquote> <img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/gof_poster.jpeg" alt="A poster for the fictional Great Outdoor Fight, featuring a train and a long text description of the fight." title="A poster for the fictional Great Outdoor Fight, featuring a train and a long text description of the fight.'"> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 6">><</silently>><p>Ray initially joins the Fight when he learns that his estranged father, Ramses Smuckles, was a previous winner, making him “B.O.C.” - Blood of Champion.</p> <a href="http://achewood.com/index.php?date=01312006"><img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_boc.png" alt="[Ray is on the phone.] Ray: Yeah, I'm callin' to register for the 2006 Great Outdoor Fight. Ray: What? Ray: Qualifyin' rounds be damned. I'm BOC. {{BOC = Blood-of-Champion.}} Ray: 1973. Rodney Leonard Stubbs. I'm his son. Ray: Hell yes I can prove it. You name the place. I call you or your local representative out. Ray: Okay, hold on. I gotta grab a pen. [Ray rummages through his dresser drawers for a pen.] Ray: Hey, sorry 'bout that. Yeah. Ramada Inn, by the airport, room 215. Thanks. [The note Ray has written is completely illegible - a large R, a large A, '2...5?', and what looks like some ??'s are scribbled on the page.] Ray: Oh, whose ass am I kicking? Yours, or another guy? Ray: Seriously? Envel??pe Martinez? Fight Champion 1997? Nice! Ray: Alright, thanks Aaron. [Ray begins dialing another phone number.] <<beep>><<bop>><<dootle>><<dop>> Ray: Envelope! It's Ray, across the street! Ray: Listen, man! You know how I agreed to stop callin' the police over your animatronic nativity scene? Ray: Yeah, I got a favor. {{Alt-text: The assumption of this comic is that you all are familiar with my neighbor}} " title="On the web, Onstad often included jokes in the title field of his comics. Here, it was 'The assumption of this comic is that you all are familiar with my neighbor'"></a> <p>Conversely, Roast Beef, who is Ray’s best friend, uses his computer to hack himself an invitation to the fight.</p> <a href="https://achewood.com/2006/02/07/title.html"><img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_beef_hacking.png" alt="[Ray and Roast Beef are riding in a motorcycle with a sidecar.] Ray: How the hell did you get into the Fight, Beef?! Roast Beef: Let's just say their database is accessible via any networked computer Ray: You HACKED your way into the Fight? Ray: Still, man, you can't hack a massive furious Nazi from San Bernadino. You got to raise your fists! Roast Beef: I ain't need no Dell Inspirion to bust a man down on into his component pieces Ray: I know you like to read Nate Small and all, but when you ever been in any single fight? [Ray and Roast Beef are approaching a large, fenced-in compound.] Roast Beef: Well would you look at that here we are Roast Beef: Watch this [Roast Beef runs a guy over, breaking his leg.] Random Guy: AUGH! Ray: Dude! What the hell?! Roast Beef: He won't compete but he'll be fine in a few weeks Roast Beef: That part of the leg heals quickly Ray: You did that on purpose? Roast Beef: I ain't Frederick H. Coca-Cola but I do know something about building a brand [Roast Beef brings the motorcycle to a stop.] <<pouf>> [Roast Beef takes off his motorcycle helmet.] Roast Beef: Alright you want a hot dog or a Polish or anything {{Alt-Text: Probably a good idea to dust off a couple Polish before the big round}}" title="On the web, Onstad often included jokes in the title field of his comics. Here, it was 'Alt-Text: Probably a good idea to dust off a couple Polish before the big round'"></a> <p>The twosome make their way through the Fight, eventually dispatching the competition, and the arc climaxes with a confrontation between Ray and his father. Ramses tells Ray that the only way to win the Fight is to beat his friend Beef raw - the man with the Blood of Champions has to "beat [his best friend] 'till his blood runs."</p> <a href="https://achewood.com/2006/03/17/title.html"><img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_ray_and_ramses.png" alt="[Ray has recently been reunited with his father following his semi-victory in the Great Outdoor Fight] Ray: Dad! It's me, Ray! From... from Sondra, you know! Ramses Luther Smuckles: Easy, boy. Don't rap mush with me. Ramses: you in the goggles. What's your name. Roast Beef: Uh hello Mr. Smuckles my name is Roast Beef Ramses: Hush, Roast Beef. Roast Beef: Yes sir [A view of the control tower] Ramses: They told me my boy was int eh Fight this year! I been up in that tower since they raised the gate, watchin' you two. Ray: How'd we do, dad? How'd we look? Ramses: Roast Beef, do I have to hush him? Roast Beef: Hush Ray Ramses: You two's tight since small times, ain't you. Always fightin' as a team, Roast Beef usin' brains, Ray usin' brawn... Ramses: Problem IS, only one man can win this Fight! Ray: It's okay, dad, Beef said he'd lay it down for me! I'm gonna drop him easy. Ramses: I though you rookies might get up to as much. A lay-down ain't gonna fly with the men in the tower, you realize. They see anything short of a cold, ruthless ass-beatin', they'll bring out the Jeeps. Roast Beef: Oh not the Jeeps no Ray we ain't goin' that route please Ray: But... but I can't beat real on Beef! He's my oldest friend! Ramses: If that's the arrangement, you got to beat him 'till his blood runs, boy. You got to beat him 'till he can't crawl, see, or cry. Those are the rules, and all eyes are on you." title="On the web, Onstad often included jokes in the title field of his comics. Here, it was 'You made your bed, now severely beat your friends in it!'"></a> <p>Ray, though, refuses. He rejects the masculine code posited by his father and by the Fight as an establishment, declaring that they should “become the ruling body, dude!” and setting the whole field on fire.</p> <p> As he and Roast Beef ride off, Ray says, “Damn. This is a thing, isn’t it?” And Beef responds: “This is completely a thing. Our every move is the new tradition.” This represents a rejection of the violent masculine code of his father in favor of a masculinity that privileges the homosocial bond Ray has with his childhood friend; for Ray and Beef, </p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 7">><</silently>><p>Ray’s relationship with his father - and his attempt to validate his own masculinity by following in his father’s footsteps - follows generically stable story beats. The way the storyline plays out, however, is less typical. Ray and Beef win the fight primarily by their wits rather than by brawn, positing a model of masculinity grounded in friendship and in cleverness rather than in physical strength.</p> <p>More subversively, Ray and Beef ultimately violate the rules of the contest (and traditional masculinity) to win it on their own terms. This rejection of consensus codes that determine who is ‘manliest’ is typical of Achewood as a strip, which spends much more time on traditional domestic work like cooking than on fighting, and generally deflates any legitimately ‘manly’ display by its characters. Within the strip, Ray’s version of masculinity is performed through its inflection of a generically typical storyline. Ray’s actions get read against the generic tropes of the medium, against the standards of the fictional genre. By these standards, he’s manly because he wins the fight.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 8">><</silently>><p>The storyline itself - a battle royale to determine who is manliest, against a backdrop of paternal judgment - is typical for comics in general, a <<define "medium">> with more than its fair share of supercharged combat in its DNA. In fact, Achewood has another arc, "The Badass Games", which explores similar territory — although there, the competitors prove their manliness by talking to a convict, befriending a dog, and baking a loaf of bread.</p> <a href="https://achewood.com/2006/06/09/title.html"><img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_badass_games.png" alt="[T??odor, Cornelius, Vlad, Lyle, & Pat are gathered facing Ray & Roast Beef. Ray is addressing them, Beef stands silently next to Ray.] Ray: Welcome to the BADASS GAMES! Ray: Badass men do not mess around! They get down to business IMMEDIATELY! Ray: Each of you take a place at one of the five tables when I say GO! Ray: Your first challenge: BAKE A LOAF OF BREAD USING THE PROVIDED FLOUR, WATER, YEAST, AND SALT! Vlad [angrily]: What is badass about bakink loaf of bread?! I am thinkink we are at least Ultimate Fightink against wino! Ray: Nothing is more old-school than baking your own damn staff of life! A dude who can walk into any kitchen in the world and make bread is COMPLETELY RAW! [SOON.] Beef [addressing a sad Lyle]: Lyle your yeast didn't bloom dogg I mean this is a top drawer failure by any measure in the book Ray [addressing a sad T??odor]: T??odor, I thought you knew how to cook? Your bread is hard and nasty. How long did you knead it for? A thousand minutes? A million? Ray [with Beef, addressing Cornelius]: Daaamn! What we got here, Cornelius? Cornelius: I omitted the yeast and made a fresh malloreddus pasta, which I rolled out using my flask. Ray: Malloreddus? Cornelius: It's an eggless Sardinian dough. My dear Iris Gambol learned to make it the summer we spent in Cagliari. '67? '68? It escapes me. [THEN.] Beef: Alright not only did Cornelius buck the rules but he made a recipe that his dead first wife taught him before we were born Ray: That is /hard/. Cornelius, hands down."></a> <p>Here, again, what makes the winner "manly" isn't his ability to fight; it's his ability to perform a domestic task. Cornelius wins because he "made a recipe that his dead first wife taught him."</p> <p>Even still, there are other texts - and even other webcomics - that showcase men cooking, being clever, and winning through friendship. What makes <i>Achewood</i> -- and Ray specifically -- different is that that same version of masculinity is then refracted, fragmented, consistently, in other mediums.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 9">><</silently>><p><i>Ray’s Place</i>, the long-running advice column “written by” Ray, is similarly grounded in gendered, medium-driven tropes that are ultimately undermined.<p> <a href="assets/pdfs/rays_place.pdf"><img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_rays_place_header.png"></a> <p>Ray explicitly posits “Ray’s Place” as a “<i>Playboy”</i>-type advice column:</p> <blockquote>At first I thought I would kind of have this “Playboy” type column—you know, real gentlemen’s stuff, but with kind of a sense of hipness and adventure. Good clothes, good food, high-end electronics and digital cigar cutters, maybe a little bit of etiquette and tips on personal grooming.</blockquote> <p>From the very first entry, however, Ray’s performance of masculinity undermines itself:</p> <blockquote>What does a real gentleman talk about, anyway? I guess a real gentleman doesn’t do the talking, but rather guides conversation in a clever yet undetectable way. Man, I ain’t no good at that.</blockquote> <p>Ray tries to emulate the <i>Playboy</i> voice in response to a reader's question about a decidedly unhip topic - "the right way to eat Mexican food":</p> <blockquote>GENTLE READER: few things in life are so uncomfortable as the enormous “wind bubbles” one’s body creates after eating some delicious, tempting Mexican food. And just what is it about Mexican food that creates such a troublesome atmosphere within us? The answer: it is a complex system of enzymatic chemical reactions which occur when soft, starchy foods meet the digestive acids which naturally pool in our stomachs.</blockquote> <p>...but stops after about a paragraph, rejecting the inauthentic performance of traditional masculinity personified here by the voice of the anonymous Playboy writer:</p> <blockquote>I feel so phony … why don’t I just try to write in my normal style?<<cite "3" "Onstad, Chris. The Collected Ray's Place">></blockquote> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 10">><</silently>><p>That this misstepping moment occurs during an attempt to emulate the style of a so-called "men's <<define "magazine">>" is telling. As other scholars have remarked, the magazine is an active site for the inscription, reification, and enforcement of gender norms. As Amy N. Vreeland writes of the girl's magazine <i>Seventeen</i>: <blockquote><i>Seventeen</i> and similar publications provide cultural "scripts" that fuel, shape, and maintain normative conceptions of appropriate teenage "femininity" in order to guide the creation of gender identity along dominant ideals. Hence, <i>Seventeen</i> can be considered a "gender manual."<<cite "v" "Vreeland, Amy N. Seventeen Magazine as a Manual for 'Doing Gender'">></blockquote> <p>Ray here tries, and fails, to write a gender manual via the generic trappings he attempted to emulate, citing a sense of inauthenticity - echoing his rejection of the cultural script of the Great Outdoor Fight and of manliness more generally.</p> <p>Even still, the advice column, like the magazine, functions like the conduct manual, which Berlant describes as a “pragmatic pedagogic <<define "genre">>, an opportunity for retraining a reader into something different and yet more herself” <<cite "12" "Berlant, Lauren. The Female Complaint.">> <i>Ray’s Place</i> has a triple function, then: it establishes the broad outlines of “male” as genre within the constraints of the medium (and genre) of “advice column”; it situates Ray, as a fictional character, within that genre; and, thirdly, it allows Ray (and Onstad) to critique and deconstruct that genre - and its model of masculinity. </p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 11">><</silently>><p>This emulation and disavowal demonstrates how the slippage between genre and gender performativity gets even slipperier when translated textually, particularly in the first-person style. Despite the deconstructive bent of the text, many of the questions Ray answers early on in the column is standard “how to be a gentleman” <i>Playboy</i>-style material - first date etiquette, the right watch to buy, proper cocktail selections, and so forth.</p> <p>Onstad's pastiche was successful enough, in fact, that <i>GQ</i> asked Onstad to produce a “Modern Gentleman’s Decision Making Flowchart,” which they published in their August 2008 issue.</p> <a href="https://achewood.com/2008/09/10/title.html"><img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/achewood_flowchart.png"></a> <p><i>Gentlemen's Quarterly</i>, like <i>Playboy</i>, is a men's <<define "magazine">> that presents a model of masculinity and sells the reader everything they need to make that masculinity real, provided they have the necessary money. But Onstad's contribution to <i>GQ</i> is typically playful, irreverent, and deconstructive.</p> <p>First of all, the flow-chart itself is an atypical contribution to a magazine best known for its annual "Man of the Year" feature.</p> <p>More specifically, take the three scenarios that the flowchart lays out: "a potential sexual encounter", "a one hundred and twelve dollar trip to Whole Foods so I can cook a two-course dinner for my girlfriend", and "a round of golf with a new client". Each scenario is fairly typical fodder for an advice column and for a men's magazine more generally - and each is deconstructed in a typically Onstadian fashion. The round of golf is successful after Ray cracks an inappropriate joke about letting "some scientists chop off [his] dick"; the fancy dinner is replaced by "DUDEMEAL, a special meal for dudes at eleven PM", and the sexual encounter is mostly in Ray's own mind, spurred by nothing more than a "chick... absently toying with her necklace so hard."</p> <p>In all three ostensibly masculine scenarios, Ray fails to perform as a good <i>GQ</i> reader ought to perform - yet each scenario ends in something like success.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 12">><</silently>><p>Ray’s personal blog is an even more personal glimpse into the voice and personality of this fictional character. These blogs are a substantial piece of Achewood: in fact, the final comic strip of Achewood's main run, before its recent revival as a popular Patreon, directs the reader to Onstad’s final blog post, where he writes:</p> <blockquote>the blogs are where I personally think the heart and soul of that universe live [...] in words I haven’t had to maddeningly jockey into tiny speech bubbles” <<cite "*" "Onstad, Chris. 'Some News to Wrap Up 2016'.">>.</blockquote> <p>Onstad provocatively figures the material and generic conventions of the comic strip as <<define "procrustean">>, and the blog as a more open medium.</p> <p>Unlike the webcomic, with its generic punchlines and action sequences, and the advice column, with its performative and prescriptive enaction of masculinity, the personal blog is positioned as unvarnished and verbose; Ray’s blog alone stretches to over 250 pages. This genre is characterized by its confessional character, and thus lends itself a kind of introspection designed to puncture norms; rather than an outward-facing persona, on one's blog one can speak from "the heart and soul".</p> <p>In an early entry, for example, Ray describes how much he enjoys <i>Sex in the City</i> and wishes he could “hang with ladies like that [...] some ladies who tell it like it is and like to throw one back.” He explains his acquisition of the <i>Sex in the City</i> DVDs, however, as a mistake: he meant to order pornography. Even in the context of a personal blog aimed at his “chochachos” (a made up word Ray uses to describe his readers), Ray explains away his introduction to feminine culture by reasserting his masculinity. He’s pulled simultaneously towards the ‘feminized’ confessional genre of the online diary, which he engages elsewhere in the blogs, and being "maddeningly jockied" into the genre of masculinity.</p> <p>By reading his performance on the blogs alongside his other mediated selves, however, we can see how flimsy that masculinity is. Even as one of the arbiters of maleness within (and, for the superfans who can come up with an Achewood quote for every situation, without) the world of Achewood - writing advice columns for <i>GQ</i>, winning the Great Outdoor Fight - Ray’s membership in manliness as a genre is constantly in question and must constantly be reasserted.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 13">><</silently>><p>In 2023, after a long period of silence, Onstad announced his return to web publishing with the release of <a href="https://raybot.help/">RayBot</a>, a <<define "LLM">>-powered bot trained on the combined corpus of <i>Achewood</i>, along with content written specifically to turn Raybot into an accurate mimic of Ray's inimitable voice.</p> <img src="assets/imgs/achewood_raybot.png" style="max-width:50%;"> <p>This bot is the result of a kind of <<define "technonecromancy">>, rebooting a defunct fictional character from the dead by feeding everything he was into a model and asking it to <<"spit out new words" "Text Generation">>spit out new words. And, somewhat shockingly, it worked pretty well; the bot got positive press coverage, which contributed to the successful launch of Onstad's Patreon, and fans generally responded well, sharing the best, most Raylike responses in a Discord server.</p> <p>Raybot was successful because Ray has a well-defined voice that his readers can recognize, and because the genre of the advice column mitigates some of the shortfalls of the chatbot as a medium. In technocratic jargon, an advice column is "low hanging fruit"; a single query with a single response doesn't rely on a good long-term memory or coherence over the course of a conversation - two challenges with contemporary large language models. Additionally, the use case here lacks some of the <<define "risk" "AI risk">> that characterizes many of the higher-profile uses of large language models; nobody's insurance claim is being denied because of what Raybot says.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Achewood 14">><</silently>><p>To conclude, Ray's multimedia masculinity is exemplary but not unique; one could look to Roast Beef’s alt zines or Nice Pete’s violently misogynistic novellas for other figurations of manliness refracted through and constrained by generic conventions.</p> <p>In Achewood and in contemporary online culture, social gestures refract through the mediums on which they are performed, become legible only in their <<define "genre" "generic">> contexts, and situate their performer within this complex matrix. <<define "multimedial" "Multimediated">> masculinity differs primarily in its triangulating function - individual performances across a broad band of media simultaneously provide the illusion of internal consistency (the ‘voice’ remains the same) and showcase how flexible, generically, any individual’s performance is.</p> <p>It also highlights the porousness of the boundary between mediated fictional characters and mediated ‘real’ persons; if our own personal production of ‘content’ through the various platforms on which we increasingly live our lives is self-consciously chosen, written in a way to conform with the twin generic demands of our media and our genders, then the gendered subject is always, to a greater or lesser degree, a fictional one.</p> <p>I do not mean to reinscribe face-to-face interaction as an escape from this generic double-bind; in-person social behavior, too, is governed by generic codes of acceptability and legibility. What multimedia masculinity offers is a way of illuminating these codes by deconstructing the boundary between the self-consciously constructed fictionality of, say, a cartoon cat, written into being on a variety of platforms, that selfsame cartoon cat's digital shadow as projected by an AI model onto the contemporary internet, and the analogous fictionality and multimodality of the narrative human subject in the information age.</p> [[Return->Section 1: GESTURE]]<h1>"Skin and Air": Remediation and Power in <i>Ma Rainey's Black Bottom</i></h1> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/mrbb.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>"Ma Rainey's Black Bottom", as performed by Ma Rainey herself, recorded in 1924 and released by Paramount Records. This recording is in the public domain.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 1">><</silently>><p>August Wilson’s 1982 play <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i> opens in a recording studio, on two white men - Irvin, Ma Rainey’s agent, and Sturdyvant, the owner of the studio and the record label - testing their technology in advance of a session with Rainey and her band. Irvin hooks up a microphone while Sturdyvant watches from above, ensconced in what the script calls the “control booth"<<cite "x" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">> that is, in most productions, located physically above the main stage, like a prison guard's tower. This distance spatializes Wilson's description of Sturdyvant as a man who is "preoccupied with money... insensitive to black performers and prefers to deal with them at arm's length" <<cite "17" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">></p> <<set _slides to ['assets/imgs/mr_nt_set.jpeg', 'assets/imgs/mr_netflix_set.png', 'assets/imgs/mr_wt_set.jpeg']>> <figure> <img style="width:100%" @src=[_slides[0]]> <figcaption>The set for the National Theater's 2016 production of the play. The stained steel control room here especially recalls a guard tower. <br>Photo by Johan Persson courtesy of the National Theatre.</figcaption> </figure> <figure> <img style="width:100%" @src=[_slides[2]]> <figcaption>The set for the Writer's Theater 2019 production of the play. Note the conspicuous speaker that allows Irvin and Sturdyvant to give their orders without leaving the control room. <br>Photo by Michael Brosilow courtesy of New City Stage.</figcaption> </figure> <figure> <img style="width:100%" @src=[_slides[1]]> <figcaption>The set for Netflix's 2021 production of the play. Despite its cinematic medium, the Netflix adaptation largely confines itself to a stage set, with the exception of the conclusion. <br>Photo by David Lee courtesy of Netflix.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 2">><</silently>><p>Sturdyvant expects trouble from Rainey: “I don’t care what she calls herself,” he hollers at Irvin, “I’m not putting up with it. I just want to get her in here … record those songs on that list … and get her out. Just like <<define "clockwork">>, huh?” <<cite "18" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">>. When Rainey ultimately arrives, however - after the white men, her band, and the play’s audience has been waiting for about an hour - she’s anything but clockwork. Whereas Sturdyvant wants a singing automaton he can record and sell, Rainey is defiantly and powerfully a human body from the moment she fills the stage.</p> <p> Wilson plays with this technologic/organic binary throughout the play: a technological whiteness, represented primarily by Sturdyvant, obsessed with clock-time and allied with the recording process, against a stubbornly embodied blackness, represented primarily although not exclusively by Rainey, who Wilson identifies with live performance and with the ‘real’ blues.</p> <p>The play stages a power struggle between these two poles, with Rainey insisting on her own bodiliness in the face of Sturdyvant and Irvin’s attempt to transmute her voice into a valuable commodity. Although this binary makes for compelling drama and speaks to the history of (largely white) exploitation of black musicians, it fails to capture the degree to which the historical Rainey took ownership of the recording technology that made her a household name - and threatens to renaturalize a rhetoric that equates blackness with an atavistic, primitive ‘soulfulness.’ This section will begin, then, by sketching out how Wilson stages this binary, before problematizing it with reference to the historical Rainey’s own stage show and to Wilson’s own words outside of the playtext.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 3">><</silently>><p>Through most of the play Sturdyvant is in a control-box, physically alienated from the recording session, and his commands come through a speaker in the recording studio. In contrast to Rainey, for whom lived experience is paramount, Sturdyvant’s speech suggests a subjectivity obsessed with <<define "clock-time" "clockwork">>. As I noted earlier, he wants the session to go “like clockwork;” when Rainey is late, he asks Irvin “Do you know what time it is? Have you looked at the clock?” <<cite "47" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">>, and when Rainey wants to stop the session for her coca-cola, he tells her “Wait just a minute, Ma … you come in an hour late … we’re way behind schedule as it is.” Indeed, it’s easy to read Slow Drag’s declaration that “the white man don’t know how to have a good time" <<cite "41" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">> as an indictment of Sturdyvant’s technologized obsession with the clock. Sturdyvant himself, then, can be read as the clockwork man that he wants to make Rainey into, having thoroughly internalized a mechanized, penny-pinching, second-counting mode of living.</p> <figure> <img style="width:75%" src="assets/imgs/mr_clockworkman.png"> <figcaption>Generated with Midjourney with prompt: 'a clockwork man in a 1920s recording studio, against a pure black background, in the style of Paul Klee'.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 4">><</silently>><p>Conversely, Ma Rainey’s recalcitrance throughout the recording session refers repeatedly back to her body. We’re told early in the play that she complained during a previous session of her sore throat. This time around, she starts by lambasting Sturdyvent for keeping the studio too cold:</p> <blockquote>MA RAINEY: Why you all keep it so cold in here? Sturdyvant try and pinch every penny he can. You all wanna make some records, you better put some heat on in here or give me back my coat” <<cite "53" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">>.</blockquote> <p>And although her throat’s fine this time around, she stops the recording session when she realizes that she hasn’t been given a bottle of Coca-Cola. In each case, she exerts control over the recording session by insisting upon her status as an embodied human being, with bodily urges and preferences. Hence her stated preference for live performance over recordings; when Irvin protests against Ma Rainey having her stuttering nephew Sylvester perform the spoken introduction to her song, she replies to his "Ma, we don't have time" with:</p> <blockquote>If you wanna make a record, you gotta find time. I aint' playing with you, Irvin. I can walk out of here and go back to my tour. I got plenty fans. I don't need to go through all of this. Just go and get the boy a microphone <<cite "74" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom">>.</blockquote> <p>Here Rainey directly mobilizes her body - threatening to <i>walk</i> out to her embodied tour - to take control over the microphone as a tool of the recording process.</p> <p>What Irvin and Sturdyvant's <<define "apparatus">> aims to capture, though, is some version of Ma Rainey that is outside of and separate from her body, a disembodied voice that the technological apparatus means to capture - as Rainey says, all they want is to take her "voice and trap it in them fancy boxes with all them buttons and dials" <<cite "78" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom">>. Rainey's attitude towards the technology of recording is dismissive and uninterested; she reduces the operations of the recording apparatus to gnomic "buttons and dials" while dialing in on the far more important, coercive power dynamics at play. Rainey's voice comes from her body, and her blues come from her body, and she uses that body and that voice to exert power over the recording process.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 5">><</silently>><p>Rainey's power is contested and contained by the technological exploitation of Sturdyvant and his ilk; where Rainey, standing barefoot in the studio, has control, the black members of her backing band do not. Consider Levee who thinks himself a keen observer of the power dynamics of the recording studio. When he insists that the band practice and perform <i>his</i> version of "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom", he does so by aligning himself with Sturdyvant and Irvin's recording technology:</p> <blockquote>Ma's the boss on the road! We at a recording session. Mr. Sturdyvant and Mr. Irvin say what's gonna be here! <<cite "37" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">></blockquote> <p>And unlike Rainey, Levee prefers the technological embrace of the studio over live performance; he dismisses the tour as "tent-show nonsense" <<cite "65" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">></p> <p>But Levee's understanding of his relationship with the power of recording technology is fundamentally flawed. We never see "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom" recorded in the play; although Sylvester successfully performs the spoken intro and Rainey sings the song (her way), Levee accidentally kicks (with his fancy new shoes!) the microphone plug out and the take is lost. This failure prefigures Levee's unsuccessful attempts later in the play to exert power over Sturdyvant, who buys off his songs for five dollars and leaves him powerless. Levee's immediate response to this loss of power is a violent explosion at Toledo, who scuffs Levee's shoe accidentally. Where Rainey uses her body and her voice to control the recording session, Levee's body gets in the way, with fatal consequences.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 6">><</silently>><p>Rainey's references to her body makes sense because the blues she sings are inextricable from her corporeal self. The first song that the audience sees her sing is a verse of "Those Dogs of Mine,” a song about her aching feet, after removing her shoes and rubbing her soles.</p> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/mr_tdom.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>"Those Dogs Of Mine" was recorded in 1924 by the historical Ma Rainey and released by Paramount Records. This recording is in the public domain.</figcaption> </figure> <blockquote> Out for a walk, I stopped to talk<br> Oh, how my corns did burn<br> I had to keep on the shady side of the street<br> To keep out the light of the sun<br> <br> Oh, Lord, these dogs of mine<br> They sure do worry me all the time<br> The reason why, I don't know<br> Sometimes I soak 'em in Sapolio <<cite "249" "Davis, Angela. Blues Legacies and Black Feminism.">> </blockquote> <p>Unlike Levee, who needs his shoes to successfully perform his masculinity, Rainey records her music barefoot.</p> <p>Similarly, the title song, “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” refers to a dance, but is also a reference to Rainey’s own (sexual) body:</p> <blockquote> Want to see the dance you call the black bottom<br> I wanna learn that dance<br> Want to see the dance you call your big black bottom<br> That puts you in a trance<br> <br> All the boys in the neighborhood<br> They say your black bottom is really good<br> Come on and show me your black bottom<br> I wanna learn that dance <<cite "231" "232" "Davis, Angela. Blues Legacies and Black Feminism.">> </blockquote> <p>This focus on the body is not atypical for the blues; unlike most other popular music of their era, the blues deviated in their "provocative and pervasive sexual -- including homosexual -- imagery" <<cite "3" "Davis, Angela. Blues Legacies and Black Feminism.">>. While not all of Rainey's music is focused on her body, Wilson's selection of songs that identify her music with her corporeal self highlights the difference between her and Sturdyvant, and sets up an oppositional relationship between her black body and the white technology of the recording studio. As Alan Nadel writes, Rainey’s “singing isn’t something already formed but something formed in the act” <<cite "16" "Nadel, Alan. May All Your Fences Have Gates.">> - or in Rainey’s own words, that the blues are “life’s way of talking [...] you sing ‘cause that’s a way of understanding life” <<cite "86" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 7">><</silently>><p> According to this reading, then, Ma Rainey represents the blues - and blackness - as lived, embodied experience against a technologized whiteness that severs Ma Rainey’s music from its context, creating the disjunction of information from its temporo-spatial context that is endemic of <<define "transcoding">> more broadly and that echoes the historical violence perpetrated against African-Americans throughout the history of America.</p> <p>This contrast is most vivid in Rainey’s figuration of the recording process as one of sexual violation:</p> <blockquote>They don't care nothing about me. All they want is my voice. Well, I done learned that, and they gonna treat me like I want to be treated no matter how much it hurt them... As soon as they get my voice down on them recording machines, then it’s just like if I’d be some whore and they roll over and put their pants on. <<cite "79" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">></blockquote> <p>Rainey’s simile recalls a history of white sexual violence against and exploitation of black female bodies, invoked elsewhere in the play through Levee’s story about his mother’s rape, but it also symbolically links her music with her sexualized body. Rainey has power in the recording studio because of her voice, and because she doesn't <i>need</i> to record her music to succeed. Again, she prefers live performance, telling Irvin that he can either record her music her way or she can "carry [her] black bottom on back down South to my tour, 'cause [she] don't like it up here no ways" <<cite "63" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 8">><</silently>><p>Wilson's play sketches out this opposition cleanly and consistently, but the particularity of the technologies in question, along with an examination of the historical Rainey's own live concerts, demonstrates how Rainey herself deconstructed this binary in her larger-than-life performance.</p> <p>Let’s first think about the particularity of the vinyl record as the medium onto which Rainey is being recorded, and through which Rainey will be disseminated. One trend we see as recording technology progresses is a moving window of <<define "nostalgia" "Nostalgia">>. The earliest example of this may be the discussion of writing in Plato’s <i>Phaedrus</i>, which Socrates worries will:</p> <blockquote> ...introduce forgetfulness into the soul of those who learn it: they will not practice using their memory because they will put their trust in writing, which is external and depends on signs that belong to others, instead of trying to remember from the inside.<<cite "*" "Plato. Phaedrus.">></blockquote> <p>Lived experience, by this account, has an <span class="glow">aura</span> that dissipates when committed to paper via writing - we might think, here, of the rest of the band’s accusing Toledo’s of literacy getting him to the point where he has forgotten “how to laugh and have a good time. Just like the white man” <<cite "42" "Wilson, August. Ma Rainey's Black Bottom.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 9">><</silently>><p>In the contemporary moment, however, vinyl records and other analog technology has itself acquired a (not unproblematic) nostalgic premium; see, for example, the discussion - by two white kids - of blues records in Hari Kunzru’s <i>White Tears</i> - the digital is “out of touch with the human body” and lacks “the soul, the vibration of an animal-gut string, the resonance of lacquered rosewood”. In contrast with <<define "noiseless" "Noise">>, <<define "lossless" "loss">> digital technology, the analog record, with its snaps, pops, and scratches, attests to its own historicity as an object that has travelled through time and demands a social relation between its recorder and its auditor.</p> <p>There are echoes of this in Wilson’s description, during 1988 interview with Bill Moyers, of the first time he listened to the blues:</p> <figure> <video id="wilson_on_blues" controls> <source src="assets/videos/wilson_on_blues.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>August Wilson being interviewed by Bill Moyers in 1988.</figcaption> <script> document.getElementById("wilson_on_blues").currentTime = 249; </script> </figure> <blockquote> AUGUST WILSON: [...] I used to collect 78 records that I would buy from the St Vincent de Paul store, at five cents apiece, and I did this indiscriminately [....] And one day in my sack of records there was a yellow-labeled record that had a typewritten label, which was kind of odd. And I put it on, and it was ”Nobody in Town Can Bake a Sweet Jelly Roll Like Mine.” It was by Bessie Smith, of course, and I listened to it, and I had one of those old 78s where you had to keep putting the needle in, and I recall I listened to the record 22 straight times. I had never in my life -- [...] And just over and, you know. I had never heard anything like it — and I was literally stunned by its beauty. [...] And it spoke – there was an immediate emotional response.<br> BILL MOYERS: What did it say?<br> AUGUST WILSON: Well, it was someone speaking directly to me.<<cite "*" "Moyers, Bill, and August Wilson.">> </blockquote> <p>Wilson’s description is intensely physical: he begins by describing the material conditions surrounding his finding Bessie Smith’s record, describes the “odd” label,” and talks about the experience of having to put the needle down on the record twenty-two straight times. His response, too, is both physical and emotional - he’s “literally stunned” by its beauty; the record “speaks directly to him,” and he has an “immediate emotional response.” The technological apparatus makes possible the very kind embodied experience that, in the play, it opposes.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 10">><</silently>><p>In the same interview, Wilson talks about the blues as an information communication technology itself, as a “philosophical system at work,” a “way of passing along information,” where the music provides an emotional context not unlike the <span class="glow"><<define "Benjaminian aura" "Benjamin's aura">></span> for the information that the song contains. Rather than reifying the opposition between white technology and black embodiedness, as I’ve argued that <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i> threatens to do, Wilson here instead argues that the blues functioned as its own of discourse network whose message was that “there [is] a nobility to the lives of blacks in America.”<<cite "*" "Moyers, Bill, and August Wilson.">></p> <p>And those recordings make it possible for us, too, to listen to the voice of Gertrude Rainey, who died at the age of 53 in 1939. Like photography, phonography is an elegiac art; to paraphrase Susan Sontag, all phonographs are <i>memento mori</i>, and testify to time's relentless melt. <<cite "15" "Sontag, Susan. On Photography.">> Writing specifically about the recorded voice, Friedrich Kittler notes that all phonographic recordings are always already posthumous, and that when a record is played it is always "a corpse that speaks" <<cite "83" "Kittler, Friedrich. Gramophone, Film, Typewriter.">>. The record is <<define "nostalgic" "Nostalgia">> by nature, but the undead voice can speak with startling vitality.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 11">><</silently>><p>In “Staging the Blues,” Paige McGinley recounts a secondhand description of one of the historical Ma Rainey's live performances:</p> <blockquote>Collectively, the audience began to call out, "The Phantuuhm." [...] The call referred to Rainey herself. Her presence was duly conjured by the Wildcats Jazz Band's instrumental blues and the audience's enthused chant: "The Phaaaaantuhm! The Phaaaaaantuhm!" The curtain rose, revealing a giant prop replica of a Victrola; a chorus dancer began to play a similarly outsized prop record on the phonograph. From inside the Victrola, not yet visible to spectators, Rainey began to sing her wildly popular “Moonshine Blues,” [...] At a climactic moment in the song, she emerged from the boxy set piece, glittering in a famously extravagant gown and jewels, to the great delight of her audience.<<cite "31" "McGinley, Paige. Staging the Blues.">></blockquote> <p>Whereas Wilson’s Rainey sets up an opposition between her records and her touring - privileging the latter - the real Rainey brought the record onto the stage. The historical Gertrude "Ma" Rainey refused to identify the technological with whiteness and instead claimed it as a part of her own show. Rainey’s success as a recording artist meant that much of her audience would already have heard her voice in their own homes; her stage performance suggests that she embraced the reach and the popularity that the then-novel technology gave her, collapsing the distance Wilson imagines between the embodied and the technological. This does not, of course, undo the fundamentally exploitative relationship that existed between Rainey and her white producers at Paramount “Race” Records, any more than Rainey’s choice of a painted cotton field as a backdrop for her live shows undoes the violence of slavery. It does, however, demonstrate how Rainey, as a savvy stage performer in her own right, made use of the very technology that Sturdyvent hopes will make her superfluous.</p> <p>And the call that "conjured" her, for "the Phantuhm", suggests a similar savviness to the way that the phonograph can only ever record a ghost, and that the voice that Sturdyvant and his machine captures is, at best, an echo.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Ma Rainey 12">><</silently>><p>By reading Wilson’s play alongside his--and Rainey’s--own history, then, we can see that the conflict isn’t necessarily between a technology which is essentially white and a body that is essentially black; instead, the problem in <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i> is historically contingent. Sturdyvent controls the recording apparatus, and Sturdyvent is exploitative, but the product-the record-is ultimately Rainey’s, available for a young Wilson to pick out of a bin and draw inspiration from years later. Rainey’s stage performance suggests how black music has functioned, in Louis Chude-Sokei’s words, as “the primary space of direct black interaction with technology and informatics” <<cite "5" "Chude-Sokei, Louis. The Sound of Culture.">>, and that the utilization of that technology makes possible the sort of emotional encounter, disjointed in time and space, whose absence Benjamin mourns and that Wilson, in the aforementioned interview, credits as so instrumental to his development as a playwright.</p> [[Return->Section 1: GESTURE]]<p>The three case studies demonstrate that gestures are inherently unstable and fluid when mediated through various technologies. This instability challenges the traditional understanding of gestures as fixed and reliable markers of identity or intent. In <i>Blue Kettle</i>, the linguistic virus metaphor highlights how language can be disrupted, forcing audiences to navigate a landscape of noise and signal where meaning is contingent rather than assured. The introduction of ‘blue’ and ‘kettle’ into the dialogue does more than scramble syntax; it prompts a rethinking of how much of meaning is constructed in the act of reception, rather than fixed in the act of production, and depends upon that receiver's own </p> <p>Similarly, <i>Achewood</i> illustrates the fragmentary nature of identity performance across digital platforms, where characters like Ray navigate multiple forms of media--blogs, comics, and advice columns--to express varying aspects of masculinity. This multiplicity suggests that mediated gestures are not static but are continually reshaped by the platforms through which they are expressed. The self in <i>Achewood</i> is never fully coherent; instead, it is a collection of fragmented performances that adapt to and are constrained by the affordances of each digital medium.</p> <p>In <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i>, the tension between Rainey’s embodied performances and the recording studio’s attempt to capture and commodify her voice underscores the instability of mediated gestures more broadly. Rainey’s resistance to the technological mediation of her art is a resistance to the decontextualization and disembodiment that threatens to strip her voice of its lived authenticity.</p> <p>Collectively, these case studies argue that mediated gestures are always in flux, shaped by the technologies that transmit them and the contexts in which they are received.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 1 Conclusion 2">><</silently>><p>The medium through which a gesture is performed fundamentally shapes its meaning and the identity it constructs. In <i>Blue Kettle</i>, Churchill demonstrates that language itself can be a site of disruption and transformation. The substitution of words with ‘blue’ and ‘kettle’ reveals how the medium of language is not merely a transparent conduit for communication but a dynamic element that shapes how gestures are perceived and understood. This underscores a broader argument that the medium is an active participant in the communication process, influencing not only what is said but how it is interpreted.</p> <p>In <i>Achewood</i>, the digital platforms through which characters express themselves—whether blogs, comics, or advice columns—are not neutral spaces but active shapers of the performances that occur within them. The medium dictates what aspects of identity are highlighted, which are marginalized, and how gendered performances can be subverted or reinforced. Ray’s fragmented masculinity is not merely a product of his actions but also of the digital environments that frame those actions, showing how medium and message are inextricably linked.</p> <p>In <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i>, the recording studio represents a medium that seeks to capture and commodify Rainey’s performance, stripping it of its embodied context and reducing it to a marketable product. This act of mediation transforms Rainey’s gesture—from a live, embodied expression of black identity to a disembodied voice that can be manipulated and sold. Rainey’s resistance to this process highlights the power of the medium to alter the very essence of a gesture, reinforcing that identity is always in negotiation with the technologies that mediate its expression.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 1 Conclusion 3">><</silently>><p>The case studies illustrate that mediation is not just a process of transmitting gestures but a contested site of power struggles over representation and meaning. In <i>Blue Kettle</i>, the virus metaphor reflects broader dynamics of control and disruption in communication. The breakdown of language in the play serves as a reminder that control over the medium equates to control over the message. As the virus spreads, the play’s characters—and by extension, the audience—are forced to grapple with the instability of meaning and the power structures embedded in who controls language.</p> <p>In <i>Achewood</i>, the performance of masculinity across digital platforms is a negotiation of power, where characters like Ray must navigate the expectations and limitations of different media. The digital environment offers both opportunities to subvert traditional gender norms and pressures to conform, creating a complex power dynamic where agency is exercised through the medium itself. The multiplicity of Ray’s performances highlights the ongoing contest over what it means to be a man in mediated spaces, and how power is negotiated through those performances.</p> <p>Similarly, <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i> positions the recording studio as a site of struggle between Rainey and the white men who seek to commodify her voice. Rainey’s insistence on her own terms and her resistance to the studio’s decontextualizing apparatus reflect a broader battle over who gets to define the meaning and value of her art. The recording process becomes a microcosm of historical and ongoing power imbalances, where mediation serves as a tool of both oppression and resistance, demonstrating the stakes involved in who controls the medium and, by extension, the message.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 1 Conclusion 4">><</silently>><p>The case studies collectively underscore that identity, much like gesture, is not fixed but is continually reshaped through mediated interactions. This dynamic is particularly evident in the contemporary digital age, where the interfaces of technology play a crucial role in constructing and deconstructing the self. In <i>Blue Kettle</i>, the destabilization of language serves as a metaphor for the fluidity of identity in mediated contexts, suggesting that who we are is constantly negotiated in the act of communication and reception.</p> <p>In <i>Achewood</i>, the characters’ fragmented performances across various digital platforms highlight how identity is co-constructed with the mediums through which it is expressed. Ray’s multimedia masculinity, spread across blogs, comics, and advice columns, reflects the complexities of selfhood in a digital world where personal expression is parsed into multiple, sometimes conflicting, formats. This multimediality echoes the broader experience of individuals navigating social media, gaming, and other digital environments that shape their sense of self.</p> <p><i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i> emphasizes that mediated identity is also a site of tension between authenticity and commodification. Rainey’s battle to retain control over her voice and the representation of her art underscores the precariousness of identity when subjected to technological capture. The play highlights the dangers of losing one's narrative to external forces that seek to define and profit from it, illustrating a central concern of mediated identity: the risk of decontextualization and exploitation.</p> <p>Together, these case studies argue that mediated identity is an active process shaped by technological interfaces, which both enable and constrain the possibilities of self-expression. The implications for contemporary identity formation are profound: as our gestures and selves become increasingly entangled with digital media, the lines between authentic and mediated identities blur, raising questions about the nature of selfhood in the information age.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 1 Conclusion 5">><</silently>><p>As we synthesize the insights from these case studies, a conceptual framework emerges: informational performativity. This term captures the way gestures, identities, and performances are enacted through, and transformed by, their mediation in technological interfaces. In <i>Blue Kettle</i>, the linguistic disruptions act as glitches that prompt a reconsideration of meaning and signal the instability inherent in mediated communication. This challenges the notion of a pure, unmediated self by foregrounding the performative aspect of identity that emerges in the interplay between noise and signal.</p> <p>In <i>Achewood</i>, informational performativity manifests in the multiplicity of Ray’s masculinity, which is not a singular, coherent identity but a set of performances shaped by the affordances and constraints of specific digital platforms. This aligns with the broader observation that contemporary identities are increasingly constructed across a spectrum of mediated environments, each with its own rules, expectations, and audiences. Informational performativity, then, provides a lens through which to understand these fractured yet interconnected performances of self.</p> <p>In <i>Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom</i>, informational performativity is exemplified by Rainey’s resistance to the commodification of her voice, which represents a struggle for control over how her identity is mediated and perceived. Her defiance against the recording studio’s attempts to reduce her art to a marketable product underscores the tension between the embodied and the mediated, highlighting the stakes of who gets to define and disseminate the self. This case study reinforces that informational performativity is not merely about the act of mediation but also about the power dynamics that shape whose stories are told and how.</p> <p>Together, these case studies articulate a theory of informational performativity that recognizes the entangled relationship between gesture, medium, and identity. By examining how mediated contexts shape the possibilities and limitations of self-expression, we gain a deeper understanding of the complexities of identity in the digital age. This framework invites further exploration into how individuals navigate and negotiate their identities in an increasingly mediated world, where the lines between self and interface are continually blurred.</p> [[Return->Section 1: GESTURE]]<p>The word "memory" is derived from the Latin <i>memoria</i>, meaning "recollection, memory, remembrance; a thing worth remembering, a memorial; a tomb or monument" <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>. The root of this word, <i>memor</i>, means "to remember, to call to mind; to mention, record, celebrate in memory; to be mindful of; to keep in mind, to keep in view" <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>. Memory, then, is the act or faculty of remembering, or the power of retaining knowledge acquired in the past, and is often used interchangeably with "recollection." </p> <p>The word "memory" is also used to describe the physical apparatus through which we remember. This usage is derived from the Latin <i>memoria</i>, meaning "a store-house, a repository; a place where something is deposited for safe keeping" <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>. In this sense, memory is a storehouse of information, and the act of remembering is the act of retrieving this information. This usage is common in computing, where data is stored in memory--in RAM, for example--and retrieved when needed. Indeed, the word "memory" is often used to describe the capacity of a computer to store information.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Introduction 2">><</silently>><p>In the digital age, memory extends beyond human <<define "cognition">> or physical records; it is increasingly mediated by technology. This section examines how various <<define "media" "medium">> mediate the construction and reconstruction of memory. These technologies not only preserve memories but also actively alter them, influencing how we understand and engage with our personal and collective past.</p> <p>Further, because our understanding of our pasts necessarily shape both our present and our sense of our selves, mediated memory gives rise to mediated subjects--and the particular interfaces of that media shape the particular subjects that arise. </p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Introduction 3">><</silently>><p>The different media forms under examination in this chapter--audio recordings, video clips, and algorithm-driven web platforms--fundamentally alter the ways in which individuals and groups remember and reinterpret the past. By capturing moments in time, curating personal and public histories, and enabling communal memory-making, these media challenge traditional concepts of reliability and authenticity. The fluidity of digital memory blurs boundaries between past and present, personal and collective, and fact and fiction.</p> <p>Memory is positioned here as an active process shaped by technological <<define "interfaces" "interface">>, and these case studies will explore how the particularities of each of their interfaces shape that active process. I will focus particularly on how the process of memory retrieval is necessarily a fraught one, conditioned by <<define "loss" "Loss">>, and how the subject that arises out of this process is a cybernetic one--a hybrid of human and information communication technology.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Introduction 4">><</silently>><p>Technologies such as <<define "algorithms" "Algorithm">> and digital <<define "databases" "Database">> influence which memories are preserved or obscured, thereby shaping the narratives we construct and, therefore, the selves that we construct. This section emphasizes that memory is not merely a passive recollection of the past but an ongoing, technologically mediated engagement that continuously redefines our understanding of what has been.</p> <p>Specifically, this section introduces three case studies--<i>[[HER STORY->Case Study: HER STORY]]</i>, <i>[[KRAPP'S LAST TAPE->Case Study: KRAPP'S LAST TAPE]]</i>, and [[online radicalization of the alt-right->Meatspace: THE ALT-RIGHT]]--as distinct yet interconnected explorations of memory in the information age. Each case study provides a lens through which to examine how digital and technological media affect memory and the self, from personal narratives to the broader social constructs shaped by online interactions.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Introduction 5">><</silently>><p>A final gloss of the word "memory" describes a record of the past, either in the form of an account or a physical object. This usage is derived from the Latin <i>memoria</i>, meaning "remembrance, memory; a thing worth remembering, a memorial; a tomb or monument" <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>. In this sense, memory is a way of preserving the past, and the act of remembering is the act of keeping this record alive.</p> <p>These case studies are united by this third meaning; in each study, the recollector returns to a past which is either technologically or thematically colored by nostalgia in order to construct a stable personal or collective identity. The unreliability of both the accessed memories and the medium through which the memories are accessed highlights the co-constituitive role of interface-as-form and memory-as-content. Personal identity is fundamentally shaped by this dynamic, and this section explores the former--interface--as a site of productive inquiry for understanding the groundwork of the contemporary <<define "inforganic" "Inforg">> subject.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Case Study: HER STORY">><</silently>><h1>Texts, Interfaces, and the Puzzle Element in <i>Her Story</i></h1> <figure> <img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/hs_cover_image.jpg" alt="Her Story: A Game About A Woman Talking To The Past"> <figcaption>Note: if you haven't played the game yet, you should. You can find it <a href="https://www.herstorygame.com" target="_blank">here</a>.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 1">><</silently>><p><i>Her Story</i> is an interactive film wrapped in a <<define "database" "Database">>. The film is a series of seven police interviews, chopped up into 3 to 200 second clips, of a woman who has been accused of murder. The film can only be watched by typing in search queries, and the database returns only the first five videos, in the chronology of the film-world, that contain the query typed in. That is to say, if the player searches for a term like "mirror", they'll get the first 5 clips, chronologically, whose transcript contains the word "mirror". The player pieces together the mystery at the heart of the game in whatever order they choose--the primary cue that the game provides is an initial search term, <span class= "definition-link"><<link "MURDER">><<murder>><</link>></span>--and the game is ‘over’ only when the player decides they have seen enough.</p> <figure> <img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/hs_murder.png" alt="The starting screen of 'Her Story'."> <figcaption>When the user starts the game, the search term "murder" is pre-filled, and they can view four videos where the word "murder" occurs.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 2">><</silently>><p>There’s much to admire about <i>Her Story</i>. It won a BAFTA for Game Innovation, as well as many other awards. Viva Seifert’s performance as Heather/Eve is terrific, the writing is sharp and engaging, and the story itself is compelling. In this study, though, I will on dwell on the <<define "interface">>--how the player accesses the clips themselves--and think about how that use of loss and absence creates, paradoxically, a sense of presence for the player that presents as complex and sophisticated mode of identification with multiple characters, at multiple levels. These mediated structures of identity can provide a useful hook into understanding how the modern subject is imbricated with and co-constructed via technological systems. In the game, <<define "UI">> and <<define "UX">> design provides a site for the rediscovery of the author in the wake of their much-ballyhooed <<define "death" "death of the author">>.</p> <p>Despite its award-winning status, however, <i>Her Story</i> has not been the subject of rigorous critical inquiry. One exception is Perreault et al's 2022 study "What Does It Mean to Be a Female Character in “Indie” Game Storytelling? Narrative Framing and Humanization in Gaming and Humanization in Independently Developed Video Games", but (as the title suggests) they are principally concerned with representations of female characters in a medium that has been traditionally dominated by male creators--to "explore the presentation of women in culture" <<cite "7" "Perreault, Mildred F, et al. 'What Does It Mean to Be a Female Character in “Indie” Game ...'">>--I will instead be principally concerned with the game's interface, and how that device for navigating and 'reading' its <<define "multimedial">> narrative gives rise to unique modes of identification which are conditioned by nostalgia and loss but are nevertheless meaningful.</p> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/hs_readme.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>The game's readme file, embedded within the obsolete LOGIC system, is situated as a help file for an interface designed to help detectives trawling through evidence.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 3">><</silently>><p><<define "Loss">>, which Lev Manovich identified as a major feature of so-called 'new media' almost 20 years ago, informs the game’s interface design. Although the game does have <<define "non-diegetic">> music and the clips have <<define "diegetic">> audio, the main aural input is ambient; the fluorescent lights visible in reflection on the simulated CRT screen of the game buzz and sputter, typing in search queries clatters like a mechanical keyboard, and the fans and hard disks of the decrepit, simulated computer audibly hum. The audio cues create three separate levels of reality: the world of the video clips, the world of the person accessing the video clips, in the fluorescent-lit room, and the world of the player.</p> <p>Indeed, in an interview with AppUnwrapper, Barlow noted exactly that separation as the purpose of the non-diegetic music:</p> <blockquote>The music was one of those things that was there to cut through the experience and create a little bit of separation between the ‘world of the game’ and the world of the player--important in establishing that there’s a difference <<cite "*" "AppUnwrapper, 'Interrogating Her Story Creator Sam Barlow'">></blockquote> <figure> <img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/hs_diagram_1.png" alt="A frame from one of the recorded videos in Her Story."> <figcaption>The first level of identification: the audiovideo recording of Viva Seifart's character in police custody.</figcaption> </figure> <figure> <img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/hs_diagram_2.png" alt="A monitor frame containing the LOGIC interface."> <figcaption>The second level: an old monitor with an obsolete, fictional operating system. The user can hear the occasional click of a mouse or flicker of a flourescent light bulb.</figcaption> </figure> <figure> <img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/hs_diagram_3.png" alt="A Macbook Pro with a screenshot containing Her Story, along with other stuff in the background."> <figcaption>The third level: the player of the game on a modern laptop, with nondiegetic music cues.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 4">><</silently>><p>Those fluorescent lights outline the starkest instance of this operative absence, which became clear for me only upon my discovery of the "anti-glare filter" buried in LOGIC’s settings. Once the player activates the anti-glare filter, the visible reflection of the fluorescent lights disappear; it is only after having done so that it becomes obvious that they were there the whole time, and--more importantly--that they were broken up by the ghostly silhouette of the player character--a silhouette that matches the player themselves. The player's <<define "avatar" "Avatar">> only becomes visible when rendered invisible by the anti-glare feature.</p> <p>Suggestively, when the anti-glare filter is activated and the reflections disappear, the visuals flatten and lose texture. This suggests how terms like "loss" are always necessarily situated, and why <<define "signal" "Signal">> and <<define "noise" "Noise">> must be considered pragmatically; ostensibly, the anti-glare filter cleans up the game, making the signal easier to parse by removing the visual noise of the scan lines, the reflections, and so on. However, because the interface <i>is</i> a part of the signal, and the presence of the avatar is a part of the message, removing the visual "noise" results in a net loss of context, <span class="glow"><<define "aura" "Benjamin's aura">></span>, and meaning. This conceptual oscillation operates as a <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch"><<define "glitch" "Glitch">></span>, swapping signal and noise in a kind of aesthetic freeplay.</p> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/hs_filter.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>Toggling the "anti-glare" filter disables the nostalgic trappings of the CRT monitor and calls attention to the situatedness of the player's avatar.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 5">><</silently>><p><i>Her Story's</i> interface more generally situates itself as an obsolete police database, called LOGIC, that’s been made accessible to the player character as a result of a Freedom of Information request. Time has not been kind to the database. The videos themselves have been artificially aged to look like old VHS tapes, providing another layer of loss and noise beyond the CRT. Additionally, the order of the clips has disappeared (although timestamps appear in each video, making reassembly possible), and (most importantly) the transcript of the interviews through which the player trawls is itself inaccessible, visible only in closed-caption snippets on each clip (a brief note, signed by "SB,"--short for Sam Barlow?--says that the detective’s other tapes were lost in a flood in 1997).</p> <figure> <img style="max-width:75%" src="assets/imgs/hs_really_readme.png" alt="A still screen from Her Story with the readme described above.."> <figcaption>This file, "REALLY_readme!!!!.txt, makes it clear that the player's avatar is not a police detective but instead a different character, who is revealed to be Sarah, the daughter / niece of the interviewees. The filename positions this layer of reality as more "real"--or, at least, more proximate in time--than the clip-world.</figcaption> </figure> <p>The content, like the interface, is conditioned by losses that imbue these digital video clips with an <span class="glow">aura</span>. Through the cipher of the glitch, however, we become aware that losses make available other points of view which redefine what is signal and what is noise. More specifically, these losses suggest the lossy nature of mediated conversation more broadly but simultaneously contradict a strict hierarchy which reifies meatspace as the only real world.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 6">><</silently>><p>If the user never discovers the anti-glare feature, then they become aware of their avatar's reflection at specific moments of discovery within the game. Occasional light effects in the play-world of Susan--the second level--make her reflection more visible. Although the precise logic governing these light effects is difficult to pinpoint, numerous players have reported that it occurs when a particular pivotal discovery is made: for example, that Viva Siefert is playing not one but two women, and that these two women are identical twins.</p> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/hs_twin_siren.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>After the pivotal discovery that Hannah and Eve are twins, an offscreen siren makes the player's avatar's reflection more visible.</figcaption> </figure> <p>This moment of recognition works alongside <i>Her Story</i>'s general concern with mirrors and reflections. The central mystery involves a doppelganger, the murder victim worked at a glazier’s and made <<define "mirrors" "mirror">> for a living, the interviewee's names are both palindromic (Hannah and Eve), and the murder weapon is ultimately a shard of a mirror. The player sees Susan's face as a reflection of their own, positioned on the screen in such a way that her face mirrors the player's own; one needn't (and probably shouldn't) jump to <<define "Lacan">> to explore how this creates a robust apparatus for identification.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 7">><</silently>><p>The moment of recognition is emphasized by the nested structure of the game. The player is encouraged by the interface to identify:</p> <ul> <li>First with the detective interrogating the woman,</li> <li>Second with the person in front of the database (Sarah), and</li> <li>Third, with themselves as a player, in a few particularly clever moments where the results of a search query seem to address a prurient gamer rather than the detective.</li> </ul> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/hs_sexlife.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>The first clip that surfaces when the player searches for "sex" is an admonition: "Really? You're going to ask me about my sex life? Isn't that private?"</figcaption> </figure> <p>The player receives a similar admonition when they search for the keyword "twin," though that one is more misleading than sincere; the "twin" hypothesis seems the most plausible, according to my reading, in a way that sidesteps some familiar problems with multiple personality disorders in game narratives, where it is often either glamorized or demonized.</p> <p>These moments recall some of the best parts of other games, where the player is abruptly thrown from the distant position of player-controlling-an-avatar into a character within the game world; for example, in the horror-cum-dating-sim <<define "Doki Doki Literature Club">>, where the antagonist Monika digs through the files on the player's computer to address them as their real name rather than the moniker they provided when they started playing. This hypermediate moment is intensely disturbing and frightening, and is experienced as a violation of the 'rules' between player and game. Interface establishes relationships between subjects and objects, and games are uniquely suited to have moments that operate transdiegetically, that grab the player by their shirt and pull them through the screen.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 8">><</silently>><p>The clunky search interface which structures the player's relationship with the clips would be much simpler were the full transcript of the interviews available directly. Instead, the user can only 'read' the transcript as it appears in the closed captions of the clips.</p> <p>The game's missing transcript pushes that transdiegetic identification in part because it is in many players’ experience (including my own) supplemented by another player-generated one: a pen-and-paper notepad where the player starts to outline the murder at the center of the game. Because the game has no set path, the player has to investigate, and investigation here means keeping track of names, places, and important objects. I ended up with a four-page web of connections, with notes on each node. Adam Smith, of <i>Rock Paper Shotgun</i>, described a similar experience in his review:</p> <blockquote>I have three pages of notes, tracking events, cross-referencing details, picking out contradictions. It’s a dissection of life based on assumptions that seem inevitable and insights that are mine and mine alone.<<cite "*" "Smith, Adam. Wot I Think: Her Story.">></blockquote> <p>The notebook, here, functions alongside the game itself as a <<define "cognitive prosthesis" "Prosthetic">> to create a system of text-and-player which extends the game interface out into the physical world as it interpolates the player into the gameworld. This system, which can be compared usefully to [[Krapp->Krapp 4]] with his boxes and tapes and to the radicalized [[Caleb Cain->Meatspace: THE ALT-RIGHT]], can be interrogated as a useful model for the systems of subject-and-technological-objects that constitute our selves in the information age.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 9">><</silently>><p>This system can be provocatively described as what N. Katherine Hayles calls a <<define "cognitive assemblage">>:</p> <blockquote>tighter or looser collections of technical objects and human participants through which cognitions circulate in the form of information, interpretations, and meanings.<<cite "10" "Hayles, N. Katherine.
