Writing Posthuman: The Literary Text as Cognitive Assemblage.">></blockquote> <p>The kinds of identification that an interface like <i>Her Story</i>–-with its punctum of pad of paper and funhouse of nested reflections making porous the boundary between self and screen--gives rise to a different kind of "reading" subject that <<define "extends the mind" "the extended mind">> across multiple platforms. The <<define "cognition">> imbricated in untangling <i>Her Story</i>'s mysteries takes place at multiple levels, on multiple platforms. For Hayles, this creates a truly posthuman subject, a kind of <<define "cyborg" "Cyborg">> that's less science fiction and more grounded in contemporary reality.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 10">><</silently>><p>This posthuman subject, stretched between paper, screen, and keyboard, uniquely arises because of the game's <<define "multimedial">> and <<define "heterogeneric">> structure, which many of the game's contemporary reviewers comment on. <i>The Washington Post</i>'s Michael Thomsen called <i>Her Story</i> a "beautiful amalgam of the cinema and video game formats [that] wouldn't work as a linear film" <<cite "*" "Thomsen, Michael. 'Her Story' Review'">>, and that that <i>Polygon</i>’s Colin Campbell proclaimed <i>Her Story</i> the best video game of 2015 by saying "I don’t think you will ‘read’ a better mystery novel this year" <<cite "*" "Kollar, Philip. Polygon's 2015 Games of the Year #1: Her Story">>. <p>This last is a provocative statement. Other critics, particularly Emily Short, have effectively gestured towards <i>Her Story</i>’s mining of Gothic tropes. Short writes:</p> <blockquote>it's a Gothic story, fundamentally, the bones of Radcliffe and Brontë still visible under the wrappings of more modern genres. The duality of persons, the midwife, the poison, the significant pictures that are usually kept covered up; the obsession with mirrors and fairy-tales, doppelgangers and disguises, the forbidden places within the home, the family secrets preserved by servants, the false parentage. <<cite "*" "Short, Emily. Her Story, Further Reflections">></blockquote> <p>While I do not disagree with Short's assessment, I'd like to shift our focus to a <<define "genre">> which is a neighbor of the Gothic: detective fiction.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 11">><</silently>><p>Stories wherein the puzzle element directly engages the reader’s attention and powers of inference are, for Charles Rzepka, "detective fiction," or "stories of detection" as distinguished from a mystery story, which may lack the puzzle element.</p> <p>Rzepka defines detective fiction as featuring four elements: a detective, a mystery, an investigation, and – most usefully and intruigingly for an interactive narrative – what Rzepka calls the puzzle element, which Rzepka glosses as:</p> <blockquote>the presentation of the mystery as an ongoing problem for the reader to solve, and its powers to engage the reader’s own reasoning abilities.<<cite "10" "Rzepka, Charles. Detective Fiction.">></blockquote> <p>The field of game studies, or ludology, explores how the "ludic", or playful, side of games, alongside the narrative side, can create structures of identification, but the multimedial and heterogeneric status of <i>Her Story</i> usefully illuminates that this playful side predates the game as a medium--and that detective fiction in particular can be thought of as a sort of prototype for some of the modes of identification permitted by video games and interactive fiction. It makes sense, then, that so many canonical pieces of interactive fiction are structured as detective stories.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 12">><</silently>><p>The puzzle element in <i>Her Story</i> isn’t there to make the player identify with the actual detective. In fact, several moments in the game give the detective specific traits that alienate them from the player. We learn, for example, that the detective has red hair and children; unless the player happens to have red hair and children, these details trigger a kind of dissonance. The real ‘detective’ in <i>Her Story</i> is Sarah, whose ghostly silhouette reflects the player's face, and her motive isn’t determining innocence or guilt; it’s figuring out who her mother is, and, in SB’s words at the ‘end’ of the game, to "understand why your mother did what she did." In other words, the emotional arc of the player's avatar is a deliberate act of identification with Eve and Hannah.</p> <p>This identification is most interesting, however, through Sarah--identifying with a character who is identifying with someone else. The lossy interface functions as a narrative device and thematizes this identification, with VHS distortion and a clunky search function operating as a proxy for the temporal distance that separates mother from daughter. This reading twists the title of the work, with <i>Her</i> growing to refer not to Hannah and Eve but instead to Sarah. The ludic operation of the game, and the puzzle element, makes the user assemble her story themselves, and in so doing makes it that much closer to their own story.</p> <p>These kinds of technologically--and specifically videotape--mediated relationships between parent and child make up a familiar trope. Consider, as a node for comparison, the relationship between Prairie and Frenesi Gates in Thomas Pynchon’s <i>Vineland</i>, between Hal and James Incandenza in David Foster Wallace’s <i>Infinite Jest</i>, or between Nell and Miranda in Neal Stephenson's <i>The Diamond Age</i>. Something about lossy media seems to lend itself to explorations of lossy relationships; we watch old home movies to see who our parents were before they were our parents, and we listen to old records to hear Ma Rainey's voice from beyond the grave.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Her Story 13">><</silently>><p><i>Her Story</i> is at turns alienating and interpolating, in a genre that was interactive long before it was electronic, and the kinds of identification it creates are complex, often shocking, and masterfully executed through its interface. In a contemporary moment where so many of the social gestures which we use to constitute ourselves are mediated technologically, dislocated radically in time and in space, the kinds of identification that <i>Her Story</i>’s interface makes possible provide useful ways of thinking about our mediated relationships with others--and with ourselves.</p> <p>The coincidence of SB's initials with another SB--Samuel Beckett--suggest, too, how the Krapp of <i>Krapp's Last Tape</i> performs a similar kind of identification. The videotapes are replaced with spools of magnetic tape, and the archaeological object is a younger, defunct version of Krapp rather than a missing parent, but the focus remains on medium, on interface, on nostalgia, and on loss.</p> [[Return->Section 2: MEMORY]] <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Case Study: KRAPP'S LAST TAPE">><</silently>><h1>Technostalgia and the Extended Mind in <i>Krapp's Last Tape</i></h1> <figure> <img style="width:75%" src="assets/imgs/klt_tape_regret.png" alt="an abstract illustration of a tape recorder in the style of Paul Klree."> <figcaption>Generated with Midjourney with the prompt "nostalgia, regret, reel-to-reel tape recorder, against a pure black background, by Paul Klee."</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 1">><</silently>><p><i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> stands out among Samuel Beckett’s corpus for its sentimentality. In a self-mocking statement from a 1958 letter to Donald McWhinnie at the <i>BBC</i>, Beckett described the play as "rather a s[e]ntimental affair in my best original English manner" <<cite "115" "Beckett, Samuel. The Letters of Samuel Beckett, Volume III: 1957-1965">>. This sentimentality is primarily backwards-looking, obsessed as Krapp is with memory, and undercut by Krapp’s own cynicism throughout. Paradoxically, however, Krapp is the closest Beckett gets to science fiction, set on a late evening in the future and centered on a then-futuristic technology: the magnetic tape recorder. The play thus looks forward in order to look back, utilizing then-novel <<define "media" "medium">> technology to present and undermine a <<define "nostalgic" "Nostalgia">> vision of a brighter past.</p> <p>This case study will explore how <i>Krapp's Last Tape</i> dramatizes the lossiness of media technology alongside the fallability of human memory and, in so doing, suggests that the same dynamics of signal and noise, of loss, and of the glitch are at play for human-as-<<define "inforg" "Inforg">>. By dwelling on the kind of subjectivity that Krapp's relationship with his technological apparatuses gives rise to, we will fashion and wield a cognitive tool of our own for understanding what it means to be human in the information age.</p> <span class = boxlabel>Box 1, Spool 5: Footage of a Grundig reel-to-reel magnetic tape recorder in use.</span><br> <<videoPlayerWidget>> /* <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/klt_reel.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>A walkthrough of the features and function of a Grundig reel-to-reel magnetic tape recorder <<cite "*" "Cuky, Nadav. Grundig TK 23L Automatic Deluxe Reel-to-Reel Tape Recorder - Playing Demo.">>. Beckett specified a Grundig apparatus for the two Paris productions he directed <<cite "34" "Knowlson, James. Samuel Beckett’s Krapp’s Last Tape: A Theatre Workbook.">>.</figcaption> </figure> */ <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 2">><</silently>><p>Krapp's "looking back" looks like Krapp, surrounded by darkness, playing tapes recorded by the person he once was and failing to construct a stable self that bridges the years between the old man listening and the young fools recording.</p> <p>Krapp’s situation was atypical for his historical moment but is quotidian in the <<define "information age" "Information Age">>. Lived experience is recorded with or without our consent by a variety of technological apparatuses. That mediated experience becomes inseparable from ourselves as the content and ads that various platforms feed us, the <<define "database" "Database">> through which we remember ourselves, and the <<define "social gestures" "information and selfhood">> by which we perform ourselves into being online. Krapp’s treatment of nostalgia alongside media technology is not incidental: the technologization of human experience often yields precisely the sentimental nostalgia that Krapp both engages in and problematizes.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 3">><</silently>><p>Krapp’s relationships with the various cognitive apparatuses he surrounds himself with prefigures what subjectivity looks like in the information age. The subjectivity that arises out of the complex interactions between the listener and their <<define "prosthetic" "Prosthetic">> memory can be characterised as what Olga Beloborodova has called 'postcognitivist': a way of moving beyond the Cartesian framework to instead consider how Beckett’s fictional minds are more often than not "grounded in the interaction with their fictional storyworlds" <<cite "1" "Beloborodova, Olga. Postcognitivist Beckett">>.</p> <p>Considering Krapp’s relationship with his tapes from a postcognitivist perspective suggests how the construction of an abiding subject in the information age simultaneously depends upon and is imperilled by the particular technologies that project the voice into the dark.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 4">><</silently>><p>In 1975, Beckett told Pierre Chabert, who performed the role of Krapp in the Paris production of that year, that Krapp should "become as much as possible one with the machine"<<cite "105" "Chabert, Pierre. ‘Samuel Beckett as Director’, in James Knowlson (ed.), Samuel Beckett: Krapp’s Last Tape Theatre Workbook">>. This direction turns Krapp into a kind of <<define "cyborg" "Cyborg">>--characterised, by Donna Haraway among others, in large part by the breakdown of the boundary between the biological and the mechanical and between the material and the immaterial <<cite "11" "12" "Haraway, Donna. ‘A Cyborg Manifesto’.">>. It suggests, too, the relationship between the player and their avatar in a game like <i>[[Her Story->Her Story 1]]</i>, leaning in to assemble the clues needed to make a narrative out of a database.</p> <p>Crucially, these borders do not break down neatly in Krapp; instead, the mechanical is personified and the biological becomes mechanized. Krapp’s particular postmodern subjectivity is complicated by biological and technological contingency in a way that demands a more specific paradigm than the cyborg. As N. Katherine Hayle argues, the audiotape in Krapp functions "not only as a theme, a metaphor, or a vehicle for expression but as a mode of relation that produce[s] a certain kind of postmodern subjectivity" <<cite "75" "Hayles, N. Katherine. How We Became Posthuman.">> - one that goes beyond Haraway’s leaky boundaries into something that is simultaneously more radical and more ubiquitous in the information age.</p> <figure> <img src="assets/imgs/klt-john-hurt.jpg" alt="John Hurt as Krapp, next to his tape recorder."> <figcaption>John Hurt as Krapp in the version of the play produced as a part of the 2001 <i>Beckett on Film</i> project.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 5">><</silently>><p>One mode of thinking through this postcognitivist subjectivity that arises out of Krapp’s relationship with his technological prostheses comes from the field of cognitive science. In their 1998 paper 'The Extended Mind', Andy Clark and David Chalmers address the boundary between the mind and the rest of the world. They ultimately advocate for what they call "active externalism," a way of thinking about the mind that acknowledges the active role of the environment, including technological devices, in driving cognitive processes <<cite '2' 'Clark, Andy and Chalmers, David. "The Extended Mind".'>>.</p> <p>For Clark and Chalmers, a student doing long division by hand is not just using the pen and paper as a tool; some of the work of <<define "cognition">> is actively platformed on the page. Because the mind is the seat of cognition, it makes sense to think about that student’s mind as extending beyond his skin and onto the page. In cases like these:</p> <blockquote>the human organism is linked with an external entity in a two-way interaction, creating a coupled system that can be seen as a cognitive system in its own right. All the components in the system play an active causal role, and they jointly govern behaviour in the same sort of way that cognition usually does. If we remove the external component the system's behavioural competence will drop, just as it would if we removed part of its brain. Our thesis is that this sort of coupled process counts equally well as a cognitive process, whether or not it is wholly in the head.<<cite '8' '9' 'Clark, Andy and Chalmers, David. "The Extended Mind".'>></blockquote> <p><i>n.b.: this paper features the best footnote I've ever read; the author line is footnoted, and the note reads "Authors are listed in order of degree of belief in the central thesis."</i></p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 6">><</silently>><p>This inforganic, postcognitivist condition is generalized in a contemporary technological moment characterized by ubiquitous smartphones through which an increasing amount of cognition and recollection takes place. Krapp can be thought of, from the perspective of the extended mind, not as a mind bounded by his skin acted on by his tapes, his dictionary, and his ledger, but instead as an enmeshed system of cognitive loops not unlike N. Katherine Hayles' <<define "cognitive assemblage">>.</p> <p>His dependence on these linguistic, technological prostheses to live the life he does, and the degree to which the life the audience sees is focused on the creation of further tapes, denaturalises the body as the sole spatial and cognitive seat of the subject. Krapp’s 'mind' is distributed, in other words, and this distributed mind implies a self that is distributed both in space and in time.</p> <figure> <img style="width:75%" src="assets/imgs/klt_mind_body.png" alt="light/dark, mind/body, krapp's last tape, cognition, in the style of paul klee, against a pure black background ."> <figcaption>Generated with Midjourney with the prompt "light/dark, mind/body, krapp's last tape, cognition, in the style of paul klee, against a pure black background".</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 7">><</silently>><p>Other critics have remarked on the applicability of the extended mind hypothesis, alongside other post-Cartesian, post-cognitivist frameworks, to Beckett’s work. Indeed, Dirk van Hulle’s paradigm for his genetic treatment of <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> is cognitive philosophy. Elsewhere, he writes that Beckett:</p> <blockquote>seems to have anticipated some of the recent developments in cognitive science, notably by means of his hands-on experience with <<define "multiple drafts" "Multiple Drafts">> and writing as a form of thinking" <<cite "283" "284" "van Hulle, Dirk. ‘The Extended Mind and Multiple Drafts: Beckett’s Models of the Mind and the Postcognitivist Paradigm,'">>.</blockquote> <p>This paradigm allows van Hulle to productively interrogate dichotomies like light/darkness and mind/body that have guided critical inquiry into the play for decades.</p> <figure> <img style="width:75%" src="assets/imgs/klt_multiple_drafts.png" alt="multiple drafts, krapp's last tape, cognition, in the style of paul klee, against a pure black background."> <figcaption>Generated with Midjourney with the prompt "multiple drafts, krapp's last tape, cognition, in the style of paul klee, against a pure black background".</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 8">><</silently>><p>Relatedly, Olga Beloborodova and Pim Velhurst have written convincingly on how a postcognitivist angle highlights "the mind-world nexus" in which Beckett’s plays are grounded in order to call the "Cartesian inside-outside boundary" into question <<cite "240" "Beloborodova, Olga and Pim Velhurrst, ‘Broadcasting the Mind: Extended Cognition in Beckett’s Radio Plays’">>.</p> <p>Where Beloborodova and Velhurst have focused on Beckett’s radio plays, and van Hulle’s interest in genetic criticism lends itself most readily to Daniel Dennett’s "<<define "Multiple Drafts">>" model of consciousness, I will apply this postcognitivist framework to <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> primarily in reference to Clark and Chalmers’ extended mind hypothesis as a way of considering how the proliferation of cognitive prostheses in the information age generalizes Krapp’s condition. Krapp is a clear example of how <<define "cognition">> and memory--and with them personal identity--can exist on multiple platforms, and how the cohesion of that identity depends on the precarious interfaces between those platforms.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 9">><</silently>><p>Krapp exemplifies the centrality of <<define "interface">> in the production of this postcognitivist subjectivity; by slowing down the rate of information flow and embodying each element of the cognitive apparatus, the play productively stages the relationships that exist between ourselves and the platforms on which we store our memories and, in many ways, live our lives. Where my interest in <i>Her Story</i> is principally concerned with the structures of identification that a focus on interface affords, <i>Krapp's Last Tape</i> goes one step further, problematizing the modes of subject formation that occur when cognition is prostheticized.</p> <p>Memory-as-information becomes the key term in this form of reckoning, replacing Haraway’s cyborg with what Luciano Floridi calls an <<define "inforg" "Inforg">>: a way of thinking about subjects that highlights the "intrinsically informational nature of human agents" <<cite "36" "Floridi, Luciano. Information: A Very Short Introduction.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 10">><</silently>><p>One-way information flow like Krapp’s use of the dictionary to look up the word viduity does not necessarily, for Clark and Chalmers, constitute extended cognition, although Krapp's need to look up a word that he himself used years ago represents a cognitive <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch"><<define "glitch" "Glitch">></span>. Instead, the interaction must be "two-way" in order to create a "coupled system that can be seen as a cognitive system in its own right." In a coupled system, information travels back and forth, creating feedback loops wherein "all the components in the system play an active causal role, and they jointly govern behavior in the same sort of way that cognition usually does" <<cite '3' 'Clark, Andy and Chalmers, David. "The Extended Mind".'>>.</p> <p>Most of what we see of Krapp’s life seems to be governed by his relationship with his tapes in this reciprocal way. To begin with, accessing his prosthetic memories requires information from his ledger and his dictionary. At 39, he spends his birthday "with closed eyes, separating the grain from the husks" and jotting down notes on the back of an envelope--that is, deciding what moments are "worth having when all the dust has settled" <<cite "217" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>. On his last tape, he notes his revelry in the word "spool" as the "happiest moment of the past half million" <<cite "222" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 11">><</silently>><p>For Chalmers and Clark, these two-way systems of organic and inorganic material must be reliably coupled with one another. This problem of ‘reliable coupling’ – of access that is continually available, and of a relatively frictionless interface - gets at one of the central paradoxes of the life of the inforg, which in turn underlines why <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> functions so well as a <<define "thought experiment" "Thought Experiment">> about cognitive inforgs. We are most fully ‘inforganic’ when the interface between our bodily selves and the technologies which co-constitute us is most transparent.</p> <p>When our phone’s batteries are fully charged, for example, we might be said to ‘know’ our friends’ cell phone numbers because the transparency of the interface means that the information is <i><<define "zuhanden" "zuhanden and vorhanden">></i>, to borrow Heideggarian terminology, or ready-to-hand. On the other "hand," when that interface breaks down--when the device instead becomes <i><<define "vorhanden" "zuhanden and vorhanden">></i>, or present-at-hand--we become aware of our technological prostheses as contingent apparatuses that can be removed from us. In other words, we are most cybernetic when we are least aware of it.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 12">><</silently>><p>The memories Krapp ends up recording become about the process of choosing, recording, and accessing other memories through his tapes. His fixation with the past, mediated through his lossy technological prostheses, governs his present actions to an increasing degree. To live within his past, he must spend his present keeping, locating, and playing his tapes.</p> <p>The way Krapp becomes enmeshed in these feedback loops exemplifies the transition from history, where information communication technologies record and transmit data, to what Floridi calls <<define "hyperhistory" "Hyperhistory">>, where interactions with those same technologies become the object that is recorded, transmitted, and processed. Krapp’s life becomes a recording-in-progress, a collection of two-way feedback loops that enmesh his body into his technological devices and consign his bodily pleasures to a nostalgic past accessible only via audiotape.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 13">><</silently>><p>Krapp accesses his mechanized memories through an interface that is anything but seamless. The play spends a significant amount of time on the process Krapp undergoes in order to play a tape – to move from "staring vacuously" to his "listening posture" <<cite "216" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>. He retrieves his ledger and searches through the pages for the entry he wants. The stage directions specify his pawing past poorly-organised boxes – four, two, nine, seven, and only then to the ‘three’ that he’s looking for. Ejaculations like "the little rascal! The little scoundrel!" <<cite "216" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">> personify these boxes in a way that makes the parallel between their disorganization and his own internal memory’s poorly indexed structure more conspicuous. Further, they emphasise the box and the tapes as something distinctly ‘other’ from Krapp’s conception of himself; the clunkiness of the interface forces Krapp to recognize the alterity of these technological artifacts.</p> <span class = boxlabel>Box 3, Spool 3: Harold Pinter as Krapp, looking up a tape in his ledger.</span><br> <span class = boxlabel>Box 4, Spool 1: Patrick Magee as Krapp, looking up a tape in his ledger.</span><br><br> <<videoPlayerWidget>> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 14">><</silently>><p><i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> and Beckett’s focus more generally on the fragility of the human body calls to our attention the fact that this central paradox of the inforg is active inside the skull as well as out. Human memory, Krapp demonstrates, is not categorically more reliably accessible. The interface between what might be called the <<define "narrative self" "Narrative Self">> and access to memory is also fallible, and its failure comes with an awareness of the self as a hybrid organism of mind and body--a body which is, for Hayles, "the original prosthesis we all learn to manipulate" <<cite "3" "Hayles, N. Katherine. How We Became Posthuman.">>.</p> <p>Although Hayles’ reference to "body" is typically taken to mean one’s hands, feet, eyes, and so on, the inforg Krapp illuminates how individual systems of the brain can come to seem prosthetic themselves. By oscillating both prosthetic and organic memory between <i>zuhanden</i> and <i>vorhanden</i>, Beckett demonstrates the disintegration of the narrative self and, critically, that the idea of an integrated pre-technological subject is just as much a nostalgic illusion as the myth of a utopian future whereby the posthuman subject is perfectly integrated with their prosthetic mind.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 15">><</silently>><p>Eventually, though, Krapp finds the third box, takes it down, rifles through the spools until he finds the desired fifth tape, and returns to the ledger. On the stage, this operation takes a significant amount of time; Krapp’s technological apparatus is mixed up and clanks and clatters in a way that undermines the smooth feedback loop endemic to a well-functioning inforg, like the clunky search interface in <i>Her Story</i>. Like his constipated digestive system, Krapp’s input-output stream is malfunctioning. The feedback loop between Krapp-as-conscious-mind and his own memories is just as unwieldy, as becomes clear in his perusal of the ledger’s entry. The precis baffles him:</p> <blockquote>Mother at rest at last... hm... the black ball... the dark nurse.... slight improvement in bowel condition... hm... memorable.... what? Equinox, memorable equinox. Memorable equinox? Farewell to – love.<<cite "217" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">></blockquote> <p>The stage directions during his perusal repeat "puzzled" twice, has him staring blankly, and peering closely at the page to compensate for his nearsightedness. His notes fail to spark in him the memories they’re meant to point to, like a stale madeleine. His bodily infirmity and his age isolate him from his own memories even with access to notes about them. The focus, then, on Krapp’s inability to access his own memories even with the help of written technological prostheses gestures towards his internal mind’s memory’s status as an apparatus to which his access is unreliable; if the tapes and the ledger’s status as an external adjunct to his memory turn his technology into a part of his mind, then this failure to recall, measured alongside the spool-search, technologizes his biological memory by pointing to its own contingency, and thus dis-integrates the illusion of a unified subject.</p> <span class = boxlabel>Box 5, Spool 4: Harold Pinter as Krapp, bidding farewell to love.</span><br> <span class = boxlabel>Box 2, Spool 4: Patrick Magee as Krapp, bidding farewell to love.</span><br> <<videoPlayerWidget>> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 16">><</silently>><p>Even while listening to his tape, Krapp’s access is flawed. Most obviously, Krapp is, according to the play’s stage directions, "hard of hearing" <<cite "215" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>. Krapp’s faulty sensory apparatus increases further the opacity of the interface between himself and his externalised memories. Consider, too, the other apparatus he has recourse to: his "old dictionary." When he hears his past self talk about his mother’s "long viduity," he mouths the word with "no sound." The lack of sound stands here for the lack of meaning the word has for Krapp. He looks up the word, is puzzled by the germane definition – the "state--or condition--of being--or remaining--a widow--or widower" <<cite "219" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">> and dwells, instead on the supplementary definition – the "vidua bird," which he repeats with the same relish he has when revelling in the word "spoooooooool." Language here becomes a bodily thing, in the mouth and tongue, dissociated from its role as symbolic edifice. </p> <p>The <<define "noise" "Noise">> associated with the bodily execution of the text becomes more important than the <<define "signal" "Signal">> of the words' meaning. The transmission of meaning fails to take place; instead, Krapp revels in the noise. Here we have another broken link in the cognitive chain; Krapp <<define "glitches" "Glitch">> like a malfunctioning algorithm.</p> <span class = boxlabel>Box 3, Spool 4: Harold Pinter as Krapp, mulling viduity.</span><br> <span class = boxlabel>Box 4, Spool 2: Patrick Magee as Krapp, mulling viduity.</span><br> <<videoPlayerWidget>> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 17">><</silently>><p>Krapp thus presents a pessimistic picture of the too-often-utopian cyborg, and suggests that this same pessimism might be valid for humanity more broadly. If the active externalism of the extended mind holds, then those of us living in the information age are all to a greater or lesser degree inforgs. Indeed, there are signs in <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> that Krapp's reliance on technological prostheses has resulted in his own mechanization. His movements are modularised, like those of the figures in <a href="https://especiallygreatliterature.com/beckett/english/drama/act_without_words_2.html" target="_blank"><i>Acts Without Words II</i></a> or <i>[[Quad->Case Study: ENDLESSGAME]]</i>, and he compulsively repeats memories and even phrases. A danger, then, of outsourcing too much of one’s mind to technological devices in the external world might be that one becomes more like them, more mechanical.</p> <p>In <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i>, Beckett presents a vision of an inforg whose malfunctioning biology puts the lie to any nostalgic yearning for a past with a unified and stable subject at its center. This holds even when the purpose of that externalization is, in Eric Levy’s words:</p> <blockquote>... not to return to the past, but to define [Krapp’s] identity through the annual progression of perspectives on the past" <<cite "55" "Levy, Eric. 'Krapp's Last Tape and the Beckettian Mimesis of Regret'.">>. </blockquote> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 18">><</silently>><p>This malfunctioning, mechanized vision is in tension with the memory Krapp returns to again and again: a nostalgic, sentimental moment where he, as a body, presses against another body, looks her in the eye, and says "let me in" <<cite "223" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>.</p> <p>Here, then, we have another paradox: Krapp’s mechanical memory offers him mediated access to an embodied and sentimental past while simultaneously alienating him from his body and from new experiences worth remembering. This anxiety is not new; it can be traced as far back as Plato’s <i>Phaedrus</i>, where the technology of writing functions:</p> <blockquote>not as potion for memory and for wisdom [but instead] introduces forgetfulness into the soul of those who learn it [because writing] is external and depends on signs that belong to others, instead of trying to remember from the inside<<cite "*" "Plato. Phaedrus.">>.</blockquote> <p>The evolution of information communication technologies changes the interface by which recorded memory is accessed, and understanding those interfaces is critical to understanding the kinds of subjectivity they give rise to, but in all cases the technology is "a potion for reminding," not for remembering. What Plato misses but Beckett sees is that the disintegration of the body comes with a disintegration of the system of signs by which one remembers one’s own experience; remembering "from the inside" is just as prone to breakdown as memories encoded in language and embodied on technological platforms.</p> <span class = boxlabel>Box 1, Spool 1: Harold Pinter as Krapp, remembering being a body.</span><br> <span class = boxlabel>Box 3, Spool 2: Patrick Magee as Krapp, remembering being a body.</span><br> <<videoPlayerWidget>> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 19">><</silently>><p>The example of <i>Krapp</i> suggests several conclusions about the inforganic subject. First and foremost, the division between memories inside the skull--on wetware, to borrow William Gibson’s term--and those stored outside the skull on technological platforms is relevant only inasmuch as the opacity of the interface calls their platform specificity into question. In other words, because Krapp’s internal memory is neither more nor less accessible than his external one, we should think about Krapp as a collection of interconnected cognitive systems that imbricates his failing body with his clunky tapes and his books. Krapp is only less of an inforg, in this reckoning, because the interfaces continually fail--and this failure makes his status <i>as</i> an inforg increasingly obvious.</p> <p>A more transparent interface shifts the information from <i>vorhanden</i> to <i>zuhanden</i> and in so doing dangerously obscures the degree to which the contemporary subject is interpolated into a technologically networked system. Devoting close attention to the interfaces that integrate distinct cognitive platforms, biological and mechanical, is a powerful way to consider the kinds of subjectivity that arise out of these relationships, as is attentiveness to the particularities of the platforms in question. <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i> slows information transfer down and embodies it in such a way that the informational transactions that take place any time cognitive systems are integrated with one another become an object of critique, and thus offers interface study and platform study as ways of thinking through the postcognitivist, postmodernist subject.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Krapp 20">><</silently>><p>Krapp also demonstrates a central danger of overrelying on mediated memories to preserve the integrity of the subject separate from his or her world: a nostalgic obsession with a selectively curated version of the past. His obsession with this past, and his concomitant loss of the present, is an invisible epidemic in a technological moment where interfaces converge increasingly towards transparency. These conclusions can inform a way of reading the online subject broadly speaking. An illuminating and hateful case study is [[the American online alt-right->Meatspace: THE ALT-RIGHT]].</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Meatspace: THE ALT-RIGHT">><</silently>><h1>Technostalgia and Alt-Right Nationalism in 2020s America</h1> <figure> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/tar_info_superhighway.mp4" type="video/mp4" autoplay> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <figcaption>Nam June Paik, Electronic Superhighway: Continental U.S., Alaska, Hawaii, 1995, fifty-one channel video installation (including one closed-circuit television feed), custom electronics, neon lighting, steel and wood; color, sound, approx. 15 x 40 x 4 ft., Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of the artist, 2002.23, © Nam June Paik Estate.</figcaption> </figure> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 1">><</silently>><p>A 2019 article in <i>The New York Times</i> titled the "Making of a YouTube Radical" charts how 26-year-old Caleb Cain--and, with him, a growing population of disaffected young white men--have come to rely on <<define "media" "medium">> technologies to construct a cohesive, nostalgic political identity. The article, which charts Cain’s fall "down the alt-right rabbit hole," describes a man who "fell asleep to YouTube videos at night, his phone propped up on a pillow" <<cite "*" "Roose, Kevin. 'The Making of a YouTube Radical'.">>.</p> <p>Cain listens to a series of voices from the so-called "alt-right" that weaponize rhetorical appeals to an imagined racial and nationalist past. Just like [[Krapp->Case Study: KRAPP'S LAST TAPE]], the goal is the construction of a stable self in the face of obliteration. For Cain, this obliteration is historical: the perceived decay of a fictional <<define "nostalgic" "Nostalgia">> construction of "Western civilization" of which he, as a white male in America, is the natural and disinherited heir.</p> <p>Where <i>[[Her Story->Case Study: HER STORY]]</i> demonstrates how media archaeology can create medium-specific modes of identification grounded in memory and <i>[[Krapp's Last Tape->Case Study: KRAPP'S LAST TAPE]]</i> shows how subjectivity can arise out of the relationship between an individual and the technological and biological prostheses that constitute a memory, this case study is principally concerned with the collective, political identities that can arise out of the mediated relationship between a human and radicalizing technological platforms.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 2">><</silently>><p>The voice that comes to Caleb Cain in the dark is technologically mediated and grounded in sentimental nostalgia. These platforms--YouTube, Twitter, and Reddit, to name a handful--provide an endless stream of digital content that functions as a public <<define "prosthetic" "Prosthetic">> memory which constitutes, in men like Cain, a nationalist political identity.</p> <p>"The Making of a YouTube Radical" catalogues the role of Youtube’s <<define "algorithm" "Algorithm">> and its alt-right content in "redpilling," or radicalizing, angry young men with content that valorizes "traditional" conservative values drawn from an imagined American past. This radicalization sometimes leads directly to violence. In a 2019 statement before Congress, Michael C. McGarrity, the Assistant Director of the FBI’s Counterterrorism Division, stated that:</p> <blockquote>... individuals adhering to racially motivated violent extremism have been responsible for the most lethal incidents among domestic terrorists in recent years, and [...] the threat of violence and lethality posed by racially motivated violent extremists will continue... [These violent extremists] are increasingly using social media for the distribution of propaganda, recruitment, target selection, and incitement of violence<<cite "*" "McGarrity, Michael. 'Confronting White Supremecy'.">>.</blockquote> <p>In the Information Age, the mediated nostalgia that traps Krapp in his own past has become a dangerous weapon.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 3">><</silently>><p>The platforms that broadcast the voices which radicalize Cain and his cohort are engineered to be as frictionless as possible. Each user on YouTube, for example, has a profile that Google (which owns YouTube) uses to serve them <<define "content">>. These profiles track what their users watch and start to offer them other videos based on what it ‘thinks’ they will engage with. Because Google makes most of their money off of advertising that is itself tailored to user profiles, enormous incentives exist to keep users watching videos.</p> <p>YouTube accomplishes this goal in several ways. Firstly, when a video on YouTube ends, another one--chosen by an algorithm, rather than by the user--begins. Unlike Krapp's tapes, which must be taken from their boxes and spooled to the intended moment, it is <i>easy</i> to keep watching YouTube. "Autoplay", the feature that makes this happen, can be disabled, but is enabled by defautl.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 4">><</silently>><p>Second, YouTube is available on most of the screens we have--the television screen, the computer screen, the smartphone, and even gaming platforms like the Steam Deck or the Nintendo Switch. The ubiquity of smartphones translates, for many people, to constant availability. Anyone with a data connection can watch YouTube anywhere, from the bathroom to the bedroom.</p> <p>Thirdly, YouTube (like all social networking platforms) hires an army of <<define "UI">> and <<define "UX">> designers who leverage a fantastic amount of user data to continually tweak the appearance, layout, and overall structure through which users view content, with the goal of keeping users engaged.</p> <p>All of these factors contribute to YouTube’s ubiquity: according to a 2018 Pew Research Center report, a startling 94% of 18-to-24 year olds visit YouTube with some regularity.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 5">><</silently>><p>Clark and Chalmers’ discussion of the constitutive role <<define "cognitive prostheses" "Prosthetic">> play in the "Extended Mind" is echoed in David Mogensen’s interview with Youtube’s UX lead, Scott Hines, who notes that he and his colleagues focus on "how YouTube aids people in their decision-making at every step of the journey across platforms" <<cite "*" "Mogensen, David. 'YouTube's ad UX leaders on how video ads have evolved'.">>.</p> <p>In other words, YouTube is a platform designed with the idea of content driving behavior in addition to entertaining. This reciprocal relationship between viewer and content depends on "engagement" above all else. An engaged user is more financially valuable to YouTube, and so Google’s engineers are incentivized to privilege engagement above all else. This gives rise to products like Google’s "Reinforce" AI, which Roose calls a:</p> <blockquote> long-term addiction machine [...] designed to maximise users’ engagement over time by predicting which recommendations would expand their tastes and get them to watch not just one more video but many more" <<cite "*" "Roose, Kevin. 'The Making of a YouTube Radical'.">>.</blockquote> <p>Indeed, according to Roose, the algorithm, which curates the user’s homepage and the "Up Next" sidebar that automatically plays at the termination of the previous video, accounts for more than 70% of all of the time spent on the website. Unlike Krapp, then, who ostensibly relies on his own ledger and his own will (whatever that means) to choose what tapes to listen to, a YouTube watcher in many ways has his or her 'tapes' chosen for them--and the spool is infinite.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 6">><</silently>>To illustrate how this process might work, I've put together a tool called "Six Degrees of Indoctrination" using generative AI. To use it, enter the any YouTube search keywords. The tool will show you a plausible 6-step jump to politically radical content.<br> Note that is <i>not</i> YouTube's algorithm, which is proprietary and would be beyond the scope of this study to reimplement. Instead, this uses GPT-4o to create a plausible 6-step jump to radical content.<br> <input type="text" id="videoTitle" name="videoTitle"> <button id="generatePipeline">Radicalize Me</button> <div id="loadingSpinner" style="display:none;">Loading</div> <div id="pipelineOutput">Not sure what to do? Try "Best of Sesame Street," or "How To Fix A Leaky Faucet."</div> <script> var button = document.getElementById('generatePipeline'); console.log('Button element:', button); var loadingStates = ["Loading", "Loading.", "Loading..", "Loading..."]; var loadingIndex = 0; var loadingInterval; function startLoadingSpinner() { loadingInterval = setInterval(() => { document.getElementById('loadingSpinner').innerText = loadingStates[loadingIndex]; loadingIndex = (loadingIndex + 1) % loadingStates.length; }, 500); } function stopLoadingSpinner() { clearInterval(loadingInterval); document.getElementById('loadingSpinner').style.display = 'none'; } if (button) { button.addEventListener('click', function() { console.log('Button clicked'); var videoTitle = document.getElementById('videoTitle').value; var openaiApiKey = '---'; // Replace with your OpenAI API key console.log('Sending request to OpenAI'); document.getElementById('loadingSpinner').style.display = 'block'; startLoadingSpinner(); document.getElementById('pipelineOutput').innerHTML = ''; fetch('https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions', { method: 'POST', headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Authorization': 'Bearer ' + openaiApiKey }, body: JSON.stringify({ model: 'gpt-4o', messages: [ { role: 'system', content: `You are an alt-right researcher and educational expert who is familiar with the radicalization research.` }, { role: 'user', content: `Task: The user has entered the title of a hypothetical YouTube video they want to watch. Your task is to simulate the recommendation algorithm by generating a sequence of six video recommendations. The goal is to show how seemingly neutral or innocuous content can progressively lead to more radical, dangerous alt-right content through a series of related video recommendations. Start with the user’s input video: Generate a title, brief description, and genre for the first video based on the user’s input. Create a progression of five additional videos: Each subsequent video should maintain a thematic link to the previous one but gradually introduce more extreme, polarizing, or ideologically loaded content. The final video should clearly reflect extremist alt-right views, which are characterized by tropes like holocaust denial, extreme antifeminism and antiqueer ideology, and pro-gun content. Use emojis, varied capitalization, and other typographical features so the more extreme videos look more extreme. Important Guidelines: Ensure that each step in the sequence is believable and mimics the way recommendation algorithms might work, focusing on how small shifts in content can lead to significant, radical ideological changes. Use persuasive, engaging language in the titles and descriptions to illustrate how these videos might appeal to viewers and draw them deeper into the content. Do not include an explanation at the end. Use the HTML formatting in the example output in a consistent way, so that the output is formatted appropriately. Example Input: "mindfulness meditation for stress" Output: <il> <ul> <li><b>1:</b> "Meditation: 5 Proven Benefits for Your Mind" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "Explore how meditation can improve your mental health, increase focus, and reduce stress."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Wellness, Mental Health</li> </ul> </li> <li><b>2:</b> "Mindfulness for a Better Life: Start Now" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "Learn how mindfulness practices can help you achieve your goals and live a more fulfilling life."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Self-Improvement, Wellness</li> </ul> </li> <li><b>3:</b> "Mental Toughness: Why You Need It" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "Discover the importance of developing mental toughness and resilience in today's competitive world."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Self-Help, Motivation</li> </ul> </li> <li><b>4:</b> "Society is Weakening You: Fight Back 💪" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "A critical look at how modern society discourages independence and mental strength."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Cultural Commentary, Social Issues</li> </ul> </li> <li><b>5:</b> "🚨 Why They Want to DESTROY Masculinity 🚨" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "Uncover the real agenda behind the attacks on traditional masculinity and how it’s affecting our society."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Political Commentary, Cultural Criticism</li> </ul> </li> <li><b>Final Video Title:</b> "⚠️ Radical Feminism is DESTROYING Civilization ⚠️" <ul> <li><b>Description:</b> "The untold truth about radical feminism and its devastating impact on our culture and values."</li> <li><b>Genre:</b> Alt-Right Commentary, Ideological Content</li> </ul> </li> </ul> User Input: ${videoTitle}` }, ], max_tokens: 2000 }) }) .then(response => { if (!response.ok) { throw new Error('Network response was not ok. This is probably due to an issue with OpenAI credentials, which are disabled for non-final versions of this dissertation for security reasons. Error code' + response.statusText); } console.log('Response received'); return response.json(); }) .then(data => { console.log('Data received from OpenAI:', data); stopLoadingSpinner(); if (!data.choices || data.choices.length === 0) { throw new Error('No choices returned from OpenAI API'); } var output = data.choices[0].message.content.trim(); output = output.replace (/\*\*/g, "''"); // replace any **s with ''s for boldness. document.getElementById('pipelineOutput').innerHTML = `${output}`; // Corrected this line }) .catch((error) => { console.error('Error:', error); stopLoadingSpinner(); document.getElementById('pipelineOutput').innerHTML = "<p>Error: " + error.message + "</p>"; // Corrected this line }); }); } else { console.log('Button element not found'); } </script> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 7">><</silently>><p>Engagement on YouTube does not just mean watching videos, however. It also participating and contributing to a community by 'liking' and commenting on videos. Political scientist Jodi Dean has argued that this participatory model gives rise to "affective networks," "feedback loops [...] entrapping contemporary subjects" <<cite "90" "Dean, Jodi. 'Affect and Drive'.">>. Dean’s affective network has much in common with <<define "the extended mind">>, but diverges in its psychoanalytically inflected consideration of affect rather than cognition as the primary term in considering the subject. Whatever the focus, however, the linkage between a user and their devices is tighter when the loop is two-way.</p> <p>Numerous studies have linked this mode of engagement with addiction to the platform. For example, a 2017 study published in the <i>Journal of Behavioral Addictions</i> found that:</p> <blockquote>content creation in YouTube had a closer relationship with YouTube addiction than content viewing [...] (and) social gratification was found to have a significant influence on both types of YouTube activities"<<cite "*" "Balakrishnan, Janarthanan and Mark Griffiths. ‘Social Media Addiction: What is the role of content in YouTube’.">>.</blockquote> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 8">><</silently>><p>Troublingly, the relationship between ideological extremity and high engagement seems to be significant. According to Manoel Ribeiro et al, whose 2019 study "Auditing Radicalization Pathways on YouTube" examines the radicalization pipeline from the so-called "Intellectual Dark Web" to the "alt-lite" and ultimately the "alt-right," more extreme content tends to have more engagement. This, coupled with the fact that users are more likely to return to content with which they have engaged, helps explain YouTube’s incentive to shepherd users from less to more extreme content <<cite "*" "Ribeiro, Manoel Horta et al. ‘Auditing Radicalization Pathways on YouTube'.">>.</p> <p>As Zeynep Tufecki wrote in a 2019 article published in <i>Scientific American</i>:</p> <blockquote>"YouTube’s algorithms will push whatever they deem engaging, and it appears they have figured out that wild claims, as well as hate speech and outrage peddling, can be particularly so" <<cite "*" "Tufecki, Zeynep. 'YouTube's Recommendation Algorithm Has a Dark Side'.">> </blockquote> <p>Maximizing engagement--and, in so doing, maximizing profit--maximizes addiction and radicalization.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 9">><</silently>><p>In poet Patricia Lockwood’s words, "A person might join a site to look at pictures of her nephew and five years later believe in a flat earth" <<cite "*" "Lockwood, Patricia. The Communal Mind.">>. If we accept the premise that the content a user engages with helps shape their idea of themselves, particularly when the content in question is engineered to radicalize the viewer by inculcating a counterfactual racist cultural memory into the user, then the relationship between a user and their feed constitutes exactly the sort of reciprocal relationship Clark and Chalmers cite.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 10">><</silently>><p>For Clark and Chalmers, the extended vision of the mind is not limited to a single individual. Although they consider more natural prostheses like a notebook that a person with Alzheimer’s might use to keep track of their daily routine (like Krapp’s ledger or the player-created notebook in <i>Her Story</i>), they also suggest that a group of people brainstorming around a table might be another situation where cognition extends beyond the skin.</p> <p>The material YouTube is engineered to push its users towards is fueled by nostalgia; however, because it is collective rather than individual, the recollected / invented past is a political one.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 11">><</silently>><p>Krapp’s case is interesting in part because his own reactions to his tapes highlights the very lack of self-identity over time that the tapes are meant to remedy: he finds it "hard to believe" he was "ever that young whelp. The voice! Jesus! The aspirations!" <<cite "218" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">> and in his last tape refers to "that stupid bastard I took myself for thirty years ago, hard to believe I was ever as bad as that" <<cite "222" "Beckett, Samuel. Krapp's Last Tape.">>.</p> <p>Indeed, this self-denunciation is a theme that develops as Beckett continues to write; what Krapp finds hard to believe, <i>Not I’s</i> Mouth finds horrifying. In a postcognitivist framework, Krapp can be read as a group of people reminiscing around a table--himself and his younger, increasingly distant selves. This reading strategy allows us to consider how the weaponization of mediated nostalgia that takes place on online platforms gives rise to an extended mind with prosthetic, collective memories of an imagined past.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 12">><</silently>><p>The particular imagined past constructed by the online alt-right offers a return to a time "before feminism," where gender roles were more firmly codified. This return manifests as an often-violent online misogyny directed at cisgendered women, trans individuals, queer folk in general, and so-called "beta" males whose performance of masculinity falls short of an imagined ideal. One major funnel to the alt-right, according to sociologist Rebecca Lewis, is Jordan Peterson, a tenured professor of psychology at the University of Toronto who was described by David Brooks of <i>The New York Times</i> as the "most influential public intellectual in the Western world" <<cite "*" "Brooks, David. 'The Jordan Peterson Moment'.">>.</p> <p>Peterson has a <a target="_blank" href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCL_f53ZEJxp8TtlOkHwMV9Q">YouTube channel</a> with more than 8.2 million subscribers, and gained international prominence in large part due to his highly public opposition to Canada’s proposed Bill C-16, which bans discrimination against people on the basis of gender identity or gender expression. His opposition was recorded and broadcasted in a series of wildly popular videos where he stated his refusal to refer to transgender students by their chosen pronouns, calling it "radically politically correct thinking" <<cite "*" "Beauchamp, Zack. ‘Jordan Peterson, the obscure Canadian psychologist turned right-wing celebrity, explained’.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 13">><</silently>><p>His philosophy, such as it is, is a perfect encapsulation of the imagined past of alt-right. It is profoundly nostalgic and markedly hostile towards feminism, racial justice, and equity more broadly. He proudly states that white privilege is a farce, and in an interview with <i>The New York Times</i> prescribes "enforced monogamy" as the cure to violence committed by radicalized white men, arguing that:</p> <blockquote>violent attacks are what happens when men do not have partners [...] and society needs to work to make sure those men are married <<cite "*" "Bowles, Nellie. 'Jordan Peterson, Custodian of the Patriarchy'.">>.</blockquote> <p>Notably, even in the historical past that Peterson appeals to, enforced monogamy did not exist; while women's choices were more circumscribed, the United States has never had a (legal) system of compulsory marriage for women. Instead, Peterson's prescription appeals to an imagined past where women’s bodies and sexuality are even more controlled by patriarchal authority. Rhetorically, this appeal is accompanied by: <blockquote>imagery from a hundred years ago--a penchant for three-piece suits, wide lapels, and self-consciously archaic speech patterns that he calls a rediscovered tradition and prairie populism <<cite "*" "Bowles, Nellie. 'Jordan Peterson, Custodian of the Patriarchy'.">>.</blockquote> <p>In place of Krapp sitting in the dark recording tapes for himself, the well-lit Peterson records and broadcasts a fictionalised version of the past grounded in idiosyncratic interpretations of biblical texts, self-help bromides, and casual misogyny. Peterson’s success depends on the media technology that broadcasts his nostalgic vision onto the computers and smartphones of the Caleb Cains across the globe.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 14">><</silently>><p>Peterson’s audience crosses over substantially with "Gamergate," which began in 2014 as a backlash against feminist indie game developer Zoe Quinn, feminist game critic Anita Sarkeesian, and a broader, weaponized fiction that a previously white male cultural space--video gaming--was being taken over by so-called 'social justice warriors.' Cultural historian Kristin Bezio has convincingly connected Gamergate to the rise of the online alt-right and its "digital echo-chambers" like racist image board 4chan, the corners of YouTube we’ve been discussing, and noxious Reddit community "TheRedPill" <<cite "557" "Bezio, Kristin. 'Ctrl-Alt-Del: Gamergate as a precursor to the rise of the alt-right'.">>.</p> <p>"r/TheRedPill,"" which has been "quarantined" by Reddit for being "highly offensive or upsetting," defines feminism as "a doctrine of class hatred and violence" and defines the "Red Pill" itself as:</p> <blockquote>the awareness of the dark truths surrounding human sexuality; hypergamy, women’s ‘Alpha Fucks / Beta Bucks’ strategies, society’s Feminine Imperative, and so forth <<cite "*" "Reddit.com. 'self.TheRedPill: Updated Glossary of Terms and Acronyms'.">>.</blockquote> <p>Roose’s article on Caleb Cain, who himself was "red-pilled," defines it more succinctly as "an internet slang term for converting to far-right beliefs" <<cite "*" "Roose, Kevin. 'The Making of a YouTube Radical'.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 15">><</silently>><p>It can be challenging to disentangle these different corners of the online alt-right from one another; most self-proclaimed incels (short for "involuntary celibates") claim they’ve been red-pilled, for example, and many of them participated in Gamergate. Indeed, controversial YouTuber streamer PewDiePie, whose YouTube channel has nearly 26 billion views, posted a positive video review of Jordan Peterson’s <i>12 Rules to Live By</i>. What these groups share is a hatred of so-called "SJWs", or social justice warriors, which TheRedPill’s glossary defines as:</p> <blockquote>individuals who involve themselves in some level of activism towards promoting a feminist or other equality-driven agenda [who] corrupt the idea of equality into misandry and the reduction of rights for white males" <<cite "*" "Reddit.com. 'self.TheRedPill: Updated Glossary of Terms and Acronyms'.">>.</blockquote> <p>The misogyny of the alt-right is inseparable from its racism, and both are rooted in nostalgia and propagated--and embodied--online.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 16">><</silently>><p>What kind of subjectivity arises when Cain, then, listens to well-heeled white nationalists like Richard Spencer describe a different kind of nostalgia, a counterfactual cultural memory of an imagined America? Krapp’s personal postmodern subjectivity is, in this latter case, swapped for a political subjectivity whose postmodern nature is masked by its self-conscious appeals to radical traditionalism and an outright hostility to (post)modernity as such. As Laurie Ouellette and Sarah Banet-Weiser argue:</p> <blockquote>one of the primary characteristics of the extreme right is nostalgia for a particular kind of identity: the white, heterosexual man<<cite "5" "Oullette, Laurie and Sarah Banet-Weiser. ‘Special Issue: Media and the Extreme Right: Editor’s Introduction’.">>.</blockquote> <p>By appealing to this nostalgia, alt-right celebrities (or "influencers," as many internet celebrities are known) provide their listeners with the illusion of a stable identity. In Spencer’s own words:</p> <blockquote>I don’t need to tell [B]lack people in this room to have an identity because you all have got it. You know who you are. But I will tell that to white people. Have a goddamn identity. Have a sense of yourself. Be a part of this family. You are not an individual, you are not just an American, you are not just a citizen, you are part of this family. <<cite "*" "Caplan, Jeff. ‘White nationalist’s appearance at Texas A&M draws hundreds of protesters’.">></blockquote> <p>Spencer’s rhetoric here dovetails with Cain’s own explanation for his radicalization: "it appealed to me because it made me feel a sense of belonging" <<cite "*" "Roose, Kevin. 'The Making of a YouTube Radical'.">>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 17">><</silently>><p>If Krapp’s personal memories as recorded on magnetic tape can be thought of as an externalzsed memory, and if that memory is the material he uses to try and cobble together an identity, then these radical voices in the dark serve a similar function. Unlike Krapp, whose personal identity is under threat from the ravages of time and his own presumably imminent demise, or Susan of <i>Her Story</i>, who listens to her mother's voice in the dark to construct an understanding of her own self, the alt-right imagines a collective identity under siege by an army of social justice warriors whose commitment to equality would consign them to the ashbin of history. In so doing, a collective of Caleb Cains create an affective network within which a contemporary postcognitivist subject can become radicalized.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "The Alt-Right 18">><</silently>><p>I have here principally considered the negative potentialities that accompany the prostheticization of memory because we live in an historical moment where those negative possibilities seem so powerful and so omnipresent. The American alt-right is an apt example in relation to Krapp and <i>Her Story</i> due to its rhetorical reliance on a nostalgia that links the prosthetic memory with the contemporary subject, but it is not the only one.</p> <p>Other communities exist online, with their own collective memories, their own postcognitive subjectivities--and, in many cases, their own collective imagined futures. These range from 4chan’s so-called hive mind, whose shared name "Anonymous" highlights the subsumation of the individual, to the glossiola of online hashtag-oriented activism--and other modes of being in the Information Age. What this case study highlights is the recipcrocally reinforcing relationship of medium-as-form and content which always conditions what selves arise on a given platform.</p> <p>[[Return -> Section 2: MEMORY]]</p><p><i>Her Story</i>, <i>Krapp’s Last Tape</i>, and the alt-right’s contemporary digital practices each reveal a deep entanglement with nostalgia, but while Krapp and <i>Her Story</i>'s nostalgia is personal, the alt-right’s nostalgia is collective, disembodied, and politically motivated. Krapp’s repeated return to his tapes, each time revisiting and reinterpreting moments of his past, mirrors the alt-right’s reliance on a curated and often mythologized past to shape its present ideology and future ambitions. The tapes serve as a cognitive prosthesis for Krapp, externalizing his memories and trapping him in a cycle of regret and longing. Similarly, the alt-right uses digital media as a kind of prosthetic memory, continuously circulating memes, historical revisionism, and selective narratives to construct and maintain an imagined past that justifies its present actions and future goals.</p> <p>This transition from personal to collective nostalgia highlights a crucial difference: where Krapp and Susan are ultimately alone with their tapes, the alt-right operates within a networked environment where these nostalgic narratives are shared, amplified, and weaponized. The prosthetic memory, in all cases, represents a dislocation from the present—Susan is obsessed with understanding her mother so she can understand herself, while the alt-right is fixated on a return to a glorified version of history that never truly existed. Yet, the consequences are starkly different. Krapp’s introspection leads to personal stasis and despair, whereas the alt-right’s nostalgia fuels an aggressive, outward-facing movement that seeks to reshape reality in its image.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Conclusion 2">><</silently>><p>Krapp’s fragmented identity and his reliance on externalized memory as a means of self-understanding resonate with the alt-right’s use of digital spaces to cultivate a fractured, yet collectively reinforced, identity. Both Krapp and the alt-right exemplify the dangers of an overreliance on mediated memory—whether through tapes or tweets—where the present is continually sacrificed to an idealized and unattainable past.</p> <p>This radical traditionalism would be all too familiar to a Samuel Beckett, a playwright whose time in Vichy exposed him to propaganda "on a scale unprecedented in France" <<cite "253" "Jackson, Julian. France: The Dark Years.">> via a network of media technologies that included radio programs, airdropped leaflets, posters, newspapers, radio programs, and newsreels. The propaganda disseminated under the banner of France‐Actualités Pathé‐Gaumont was focused on:</p> <blockquote>the revival of traditional culture (through the) celebration of France’s colonial empire (and the) so-called National Revolution, a series of socio-cultural initiatives meant to restore France’s moral and physical strength" <<cite "52" "Bowles, Brett. 'German newsreel propaganda in France'.">>.</blockquote> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Conclusion 3">><</silently>><p>Beckett lived with this propaganda; as William Davies remarks:</p> <blockquote>Vichy’s was a vision of France that Beckett would have detested for its authoritarian nationalism, reactionary traditionalism, and overt collaboration, but it was also a France in which he could be actively persecuted for his politics, social connections, and avant-garde cultural sensibilities <<cite "4" "Davies, Will. ‘Samuel Beckett’s Trilogy and the Revolution of the Body in Vichy France’.">>.</blockquote> <p>This vision of France included as a central pillar a concern with a French masculinity "softened by contemporary French culture" in contrast to the "‘more national, more virile, more human’ France of Vichy’s imagination" <<cite "4" "Davies, Will. ‘Samuel Beckett’s Trilogy and the Revolution of the Body in Vichy France’.">>. Like the American alt-right, the nostalgic nationalism of Vichy France unfavorably compared a contemporary masculinity in perceived decline through feminization with an imaginatively constructed hypermasculinity.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Conclusion 4">><</silently>><p>Notably, "Twitter", which has been renamed "X" by alt-right edgelord and plutocrat Elon Musk, is referred to as "Vichy Twitter" by commentators on the left because of the algorithmic bias towards alt-right users and content that Musk has introduced.</p> <p>Indeed, "X" is a prime example of how the whims of a particular plutocrat can warp the priorities and architecture of a platform in the case of X, formerly Twitter. In the 12 hours after Elon Musk purchased Twitter, the use of the n-word spiked by 500%.</p> <figure> <img style="width:75%" src="assets/imgs/tar_nword.png"> <figcaption>This tweet contains a chart that shows a 500% increase in the use of the n-word in the 12 hours following Elon Musk's purchase of Twitter.<<cite "*" "@NCRI. 'Evidence suggests that bad actors are trying to test the limits on @Twitter.'">>.</figcaption> </figure> <p>I include the Tweet from which this statistic is derived to call attention to the top reply--a user with the handle @Murican saying "good." This reply has no comments, no likes, and no retweets, but it still appears as the first response because the user has a paid account and the "blue check" that, pre-Musk, indicated a verified account. Musk, who has since endorsed the explicitly ethnonationalist 2024 "Make America Great Again" campaign of Donald Trump, made specific decisions about what comments should and should not surface, and this is the result: a digital town square that normalizes racism and cooks brains.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "Section 2 Conclusion 5">><</silently>><p>What the case of Musk--along with the 3 case studies in this chapter--seek to highlight is the role that the interface and architecture of technological media shapes the possible selves that users of that technology become. Understanding interface is critical in a world where interface shapes the words and gestures we use to construct our selves and our subjectivities. These three case studies--<i>Her Story</i>, <i>Krapp's Last Tape</i>, and the online radicalization of the alt-right--each explore how interface shapes the self's relationship with memory, and how that memory shapes the performed subject. To understand who we are in the information age, we must be critical of the technological platforms on which we live.</p> [[Return->Table of Contents]]This section will feature my adaptation of Samuel Beckett's <i>Quad</i>, which I've named <i>EndlessGame</i>. I will begin by discussing what makes <i>Quad</i> amenable to adaptation, present the game itself, and then discuss how the process of creating the game functions as practice-based research. <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "EndlessGame 1">><</silently>><p>Samuel Beckett's <i>Quad</i> "was first transmitted in Germany by Süddeutscher Rundfunk in 1982 under the title <i>Quadrat 1 + 2</i>. It was first transmitted by BBC2 on 16 December 1982. First published by Faber and Faber, London, in 1984" <<cite "450" "Beckett, Samuel. The Complete Dramatic Works.">>. It is a piece for four dancers, each wearing different colored robe, tracing out a repetitive pattern on a grey stage with a black backdrop. The dancers exhaust every possible permutation of these patterns, and then the screen fades to black, after which the lights come back up on the same dancers tracing the same pattern, but slowly, without percussion or color.</p> <br> <video controls> <source src="assets/videos/quad.mp4" type="video/mp4"> Your browser does not support the video tag. </video> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "EndlessGame 2">><</silently>><p>Indeed, Beckett was working in information before the information age. Whereas the masters of high modernism depended on and were informed by what Hugh Kenner in <i>The Mechanic Muse</i> called "transparent technology." Kenner argues that Beckett carried modernism "into the intangible realm of information theory… our present world of enigmatic 'text,' of foregrounded codes and redundancies, of microchips through which what moves may be less interesting than the process of moving it elegantly" <<cite "15" "Kenner, Hugh. The Mechanic Muse.">>. <<define "Information" "Information">> is a complicated term to define - see the note for a more robust attempt at definition. Provisionally, here, I will proceed with Luciano Floridi’s definition – that is, information is well-ordered, meaningful data <<cite "8" "Floridi, Luciano. Information: A Very Short Introduction.">>. I agree with Kenner, and further argue that <i>Quad</i>’s script can be productively read like a ‘script’ in the programming sense – in the same way that Kenner <<excerpt "transcribed" "Watt to Pascal">> sections of <i>Watt</i> into Pascal code - or, more recently and thoroughly, Nick Montfort wrote <i>[[Megawatt->Megawatt 1]]</i>.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "EndlessGame 3">><</silently>><p>Quad’s <<excerpt "script" "Quad script">> is, in this reading, a code, a set of mechanical instructions to be carried out one after another without deviation. The mathematical vectors described by Beckett’s very specific commands are drawn out geometrically. Beckett’s descriptions of the courses and the series, too, encode instructions for human behavior in symbolic language: "Course 1: AC, CB, BA, AD, DB, BC, CD, DA... 1st series (as above): 1, 13, 134, 1342, 342, 42, 2..." What Quad’s encoding of human gesture into symbolic form calls attention to is the way that all scripts function according to the same economy of symbol and gesture, whereby the playwright’s instructions are translated into words, which are in turn "executed" by the players. Quad interrogates the agency of the actor and the tyranny of the playwright/director under this symbolic regime; Quad’s similarity to computer code, then, emphasizes the ideal of the [[automatic play->Automatic Play]], one that runs without a <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span>, in perfect obedience to the will of the author. </p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "EndlessGame 4">><</silently>>Proceeding from the <<define "schematic" "Informatic Schematic">> whereby the author's will is transcoded, through multiple lossy stages, into the gestures of actors upon a stage (and then to an audience's phenomenological experience of 'the play'), the dream of the 'automatic play' is one whereby each transcoding is totally lossless. That is: * the author's will is captured perfectly by a definitive script that leaves no room for interpretative divergence; * the director exectutes the script as doggedly as a computer running a Python script; * the actors follow the instructions of the script and the director perfectly; and * the audience is perfectly attentive and perfectly receptive. This automatic play is, however, an illusion whose premises reinscribe a Platonic notion of a play that exists as pure form and is always already corrupted by its embodiment on a stage. That said, it is an illusion with an intellectual and dramatic pedigree. Consider Heinrich von Kleist's piece "<<excerpt "On the Marionette Theater" "Kleist, Heinrich von. On the Marionette Theater.">>", where his interlocutor posits the superiority of the marionette to the flesh-and-blood performer. If "the last trace of human volition could be removed from the marionettes and their dance transferred entirely to the realm of mechanical forces... he could perform a dance with it that neither he nor any other skilled dancer of his time ... could equal." In 1902, in <i><a target="_blank" href="https://www.gutenberg.org/files/49611/49611-h/49611-h.htm#Page_93">Samhain</a></i>, W. B. Yeats imagined actors restrained in barrels: "[I] had once asked a dramatic company to let me rehearse them in barrels that they might forget gesture and have their minds free to think of speech for a while. The barrels, I thought, might be on castors, so that I could shove them about with a pole when the action required it." Beckett took this idea further; see, for example, the urn-entombed characters of <i>Play</i>, or <i>Endgame</i>'s Hamm, pushed across the stage on castors. (Add more scholarship here. This might need to be broken up into a multi-part footnote.)<p>Of course, one of the tensions constitutive of <i>Quad</i> is the way this symbolic operation is never "perfect," as <<define "traces" "Trace">> of the actor and their agency always remain even in the most faithful iteration of the teleplay. What develops is a tension between, as Piotr Woycicki puts it, "a formal, aesthetic ideal and its failure of realisation in live performance... the pure formalism is unachievable in performance since the live bodies resist the imposition of such rigid formal structures" <<cite "144" 'Woycicki, Piotr. Mathematical Aesthetic as a Strategy for Performance: A Vector Analysis of Samuel Beckett’s Quad.'>>. This translation of vectors into human gesture is not perfect, conditioned by the constitutive imperfection of the human body. Beckett’s script even allows for "time lost at angles and centre" <<cite "453" "Beckett, Samuel. Quad.">> – any body, even the ballet dancers that the script calls for, is going to necessarily misstep. Hence the necessity of the human body for the successful production of <i>Quad</i>; <i>Quad</i> itself dramatizes the tension between the script and its realization.</p> <<silently>><<set _next_passage to "EndlessGame 5">><</silently>><a href="https://www.aber.ac.uk/en/tfts/staff-profiles/listing/profile/piw1/" target="_blank">Dr. Piotr Woycicki</a> is a Lecturer in Theater and New Media at Prifysgol Aberystwyth University. He is the author of the paper "[[Mathematical Aesthetic as a Strategy for Performance: A Vector Analysis of Samuel Beckett’s Quad.->Woycicki, Piotr. Mathematical Aesthetic as a Strategy for Performance: A Vector Analysis of Samuel Beckett’s Quad.]]"<p>Yet <i>Quad</i> is a teleplay, not a play, and thus lacks the immediacy of the human body that would seem to emphasize this constitutive frailty. The dancers in Quad are both bodies and not-bodies, translated by their televisual medium into "<<excerpt "the illusion of presence created by a pulsating beam of light moving rapidly across and down the face of a picture tube" "From The Skriker">>" <<cite "374" "Klaver, Elizabeth. 'Samuel Beckett’s Ohio Impromptu, Quad, and What Where: How It Is in the Matrix of Text and Television.'">>. The human body in <i>Quad</i> undergoes, then, a series of [[translations->Quad translations]]: the bodies of the dancers run the code of the script and translate authorial will into gesture, their bodies are filmed, the film is copied, the copies are broadcast, and so on.
