Our alienation from a time predicated on human experience is thus pathological, a mixup between the substantial and its representation.</p><p>Any discussion of difference with reference to the humanities must grapple with its most common appearance in contemporary theory through Derrida, as différance. Although scholars have drawn connections between Bateson’s 'difference' and Derrida’s (see especially White <<cite '17' '35' 'White, Michael. "Narrative Practices and Community Assignments."'>>), there are several major discontinuities between the two systems, the primary of which is epistemological. Whereas Bateson’s 'difference' acts as a channel between a map and a territory, Derridean poststructuralism rejects the existence of a territory itself. Bateson’s epistemology is thus ultimately foundational inasmuch as it claims a relationship between the object (the chalk) and the differences that make up the information we have about that chalk, and Derrida’s is (in extremely broad strokes) antifoundationalist inasmuch as difference says nothing about the chalk as a thing in itself and instead says something about the process of 'making sense' as a constant process of deferral.</p><p>Philosophers working in the field of philosophy of information have gone as far as to suggest that information makes up the fundamental structure of the universe. John Archibald Wheeler, writing in 1969, posited that: <blockquote>"every physical quantity, every it, derives its ultimate significance from bits, binary yes-or-no indications, a conclusion which we epitomize in the phrase, it from bit" <<cite '1' 'Wheeler, John Archibald. "Information, Physics, Quantum: The Search for Links."'>></blockquote> <p>That is to say, the fundamental ontological unit is the binary digit. More recently, Luciano Floridi’s "Informational Structural Realism" (2007) identifies primordial information ("dedomena") as the foundation of any structure in any possible world. Terrell Bynum’s "Quantum Informational Structural Realism" (2014) goes one step further, citing:</p> <blockquote> [...] recent developments in physics, especially in quantum theory and cosmology [that suggest] the universe is a vast ‘sea’ of quantum information (‘qubits’), and all objects and processes in our world (including human beings) are constantly changing quantum data structures dynamically interacting with one another" <<cite '1' 'Bynum, Terrell. "On the Possibility of Quantum Informational Structural Realism."'>>.</blockquote> <p>These theories are distinct from but related to the simulation hypothesis popularized by Nick Bostrom. In brief, given the possibility of simulating a universe on a Turing machine, the odds of our existence being simulation running on some higher-order machine vastly exceed the likelihood that this is the ‘prime’ universe. Whether or not Wheeler et al correctly identify the fundamental structure of the universe, that these ideas are being taken seriously by philosophers speaks to the centrality of information in the zeitgeist, and to the conceptual expansiveness of information as such.</p><p>Data comes from the Latin <i>datum</i>, meaning "that which is given." In philosophy, the term is used to refer to things like sense datum that are "immediately apprehended by or presented to the mind or senses" <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>.</p> <p>In computing, on the other hand, that same dictionary defines data as "the quantities, characters, or symbols on which operations are performed by a computer and which may be stored or transmitted in the form of electrical signals and held on recording media"--that is, the grist out of which computer systems generate and represent meaningful information.</p> <p>These two definitions are in conflict with one another. The philosophical definition gestures towards a percept prior to its interpolation in higher-order human cognition, outside of ideology. The technical one instead refers to patterns that exist within systems designed ([[generally->AI]]) by people for people. This conflation is key to the epistemological sleight-of-hand undergirding some contemporary discourse around data, whereby conclusions arrived at via its manipulation project a patina of problematic and ersatz objectivity while in fact reifying and rearticulating the biases of designers who are overwhelmingly homogenous.</p> <p>For the purposes of this study, I try to consider data as roughly equivalent to sensory data--that is, the preprocessed stuff out of which <<define "information" "Information">> is gleaned--without losing sight of the ways in which the design of the technological systems that perform that transmutation of <<define "data into information">> (and gather that data in the first place) are always historically contingent and often problematic.</p><p>AI is a notoriously difficult term to define (see, for example, the <<cite "13" "Eckersley, Peter. "Artificial Intelligence: Its Scope and Limits.""> discussion of 'the scope and limits of AI') but, broadly speaking, it refers to the application of computational techniques to tasks formerly reserved to human cognition. In the words of <<cite "15" "Poole, David L., and Alan K. Mackworth. Artificial Intelligence: Foundations of Computational Agents.">>, AI is "the study of agents that receive percepts from the environment and perform actions."</p> <p>As such, AI can be deployed for a range of tasks, from machine translation to image recognition and text generation. However, the primary task of this study is to understand how the assumptions and design of AI systems can embed and enact biases that reify and reinforce structures of oppression. </p><p>Large Language Models (LLMs) are a class of artificial intelligence systems designed to understand and generate human-like text. The most well-known example, OpenAI's GPT-3, consists of 175 billion parameters, allowing it to produce highly coherent and contextually relevant responses to prompts <<cite "3" "Brown, Tom, et al. Language Models are Few-Shot Learners.">>. The term "large" refers to the sheer scale of these models, which are trained on vast datasets encompassing diverse textual sources, thereby enabling them to grasp the nuances and intricacies of human language.</p> <p>LLMs operate on the principle of deep learning, utilizing neural networks that mimic the architecture of the human brain. These networks are capable of "learning" from data by adjusting the weights of connections between artificial neurons based on the patterns they observe <<define "neural-network" "Neural Networks">>. As a result, LLMs can perform a wide array of language tasks, including <<machine translation, summarization, question answering, and even creative writing, with a level of fluency that often surpasses earlier AI models.</p> <p>However, the advent of LLMs has not been without controversy. Critics point out the potential for these models to perpetuate biases present in their training data, as well as concerns about the ethical implications of their use in generating misinformation or automating jobs traditionally performed by humans <<cite "36" "Bender, Emily M., et al. On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots: Can Language Models Be Too Big?">>. Despite these concerns, proponents argue that LLMs represent a significant leap forward in AI capabilities, offering new possibilities for human-computer interaction and augmenting human creativity.</p> <p>LLMs have also sparked discussions about the nature of intelligence and creativity. While they can generate text that appears to be original and insightful, LLMs are essentially pattern-matching machines, drawing on the vast corpus of data they have been trained on to produce their outputs. This raises questions about the distinction between human and machine creativity, as well as the potential for AI to collaborate with humans in new and unexpected ways <<cite "24" "Marcus, Gary, and Ernest Davis. Rebooting AI: Building Artificial Intelligence We Can Trust.">>.</p><p>Image recognition refers to the capability of artificial intelligence systems to identify objects, people, places, and other entities within visual data. This technology leverages complex algorithms and deep learning models to "see" and interpret the contents of images, akin to how humans use their vision <<cite "98" "Goodfellow, Ian, et al. Deep Learning">>. In a nutshell, image recognition is all about teaching machines to recognize and make sense of the world through pixels.</p> <p>The process typically involves training convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on vast datasets of labeled images, enabling the system to learn patterns and features that distinguish different categories. Once trained, these models can accurately classify and identify new images they haven't seen before. It’s a "picture-perfect" example of how AI can mimic human cognitive functions <<define "CNN" "Convolutional Neural Networks">>.</p> <p>Applications of image recognition are widespread, from autonomous vehicles that need to navigate busy streets to social media platforms that automatically tag friends in photos. It's clear that this technology has a "bright future," helping machines to gain insights that were previously only accessible to human eyes <<cite "57" "LeCun, Yann, et al. Deep Learning.">>.</p> <p>However, the technology isn't without its blind spots. Image recognition systems can struggle with recognizing objects in unfamiliar contexts or dealing with variations in lighting and perspective. Additionally, there are ethical concerns regarding privacy and surveillance, as these systems are often used in ways that can "spy" on individuals without their consent <<cite "45" "Zuboff, Shoshana. The Age of Surveillance Capitalism">>. But as the field continues to evolve, researchers are "focusing" on improving accuracy and addressing these issues.</p> <p>Overall, image recognition is a fascinating intersection of technology and vision, offering a "new lens" through which machines can interpret the world. Whether it's diagnosing medical conditions from scans or helping us find lost items through visual search, this technology is "changing the picture" of how we interact with the digital and physical realms.<p>Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are a class of deep learning models specifically designed for processing structured grid data, such as images. By mimicking the way humans process visual information, CNNs have become the "eyes" of artificial intelligence, enabling machines to understand and interpret the visual world with remarkable accuracy <<cite "23" "LeCun, Yann, et al. Deep Learning.">>.</p> <p>CNNs are built on the concept of convolution, a mathematical operation that slides a filter over input data to extract features like edges, textures, and shapes. This process allows the network to focus on local patterns while preserving spatial relationships, making it "picture-perfect" for image recognition and classification tasks <<define "convolution" "Convolution Operation">>.</p> <p>The architecture of CNNs typically includes multiple layers, such as convolutional layers, pooling layers, and fully connected layers, each playing a "part and parcel" in transforming the input data into meaningful representations. The convolutional layers act as the feature detectors, while pooling layers reduce the dimensionality, and fully connected layers integrate these features to perform the final classification <<cite "112" "Krizhevsky, Alex, et al. ImageNet Classification with Deep Convolutional Neural Networks">>.</p> <p>CNNs have "seen" widespread adoption in various applications, from facial recognition and self-driving cars to medical image analysis and even art creation. Their ability to automatically learn and extract relevant features from raw data has "framed" them as one of the most powerful tools in the AI toolkit.</p> <p>However, CNNs are not without their challenges. They can be computationally intensive and require large amounts of labeled data for training. Moreover, their performance can be affected by variations in input data, such as changes in lighting, orientation, and scale. Researchers are constantly "sharpening" these models to improve their robustness and efficiency <<cite "76" "Simonyan, Karen, and Andrew Zisserman. Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition">>.</p> <p>Overall, Convolutional Neural Networks represent a "clear vision" of the future of AI, transforming how machines perceive and interact with the visual world. By "zooming in" on the fine details and "capturing" complex patterns, CNNs are opening new vistas in technology and innovation.</p><p>Text generation refers to the process by which artificial intelligence models create coherent and contextually relevant text based on given prompts or input data. These models, often powered by neural networks, can produce anything from simple sentences to complex narratives, blurring the lines between human and machine authorship.</p> <p>The history of text generation can be traced back to the early 20th century with experiments in automatic writing, where writers would produce text without conscious control, believing it to be guided by external forces. This concept found a technological parallel in the 1930s with Bob Brown’s “Readies,” a vision for a reading machine that could rapidly present text to enhance comprehension and speed.</p> <p>Modern text generation techniques have evolved significantly from these early ideas. Today’s models, like GPT-3, are trained on vast datasets comprising diverse sources of text, allowing them to generate highly sophisticated and contextually aware content. These models utilize transformer architectures, which can understand and generate text by processing it in chunks and capturing dependencies across different parts of the text.</p> <p>Applications of text generation are vast and varied, ranging from chatbots and virtual assistants to creative writing and automated journalism. These models can "write" engaging stories, generate insightful summaries, and even assist in drafting academic papers—like the one you're currently reading, for instance! But beware, these text-generating marvels have a knack for making you wonder whether the words you're reading are crafted by human hands or synthesized by a clever algorithm.</p> <p>Despite their capabilities, text generation models face challenges, such as maintaining coherence over long passages and avoiding biases present in their training data. As researchers continue to refine these systems, the goal is to create models that not only generate text indistinguishable from human writing but also respect ethical considerations and enhance human creativity.</p><p>The term ‘cliché’ is, literally, a technical term used by 19th century printers, coming from the verb ‘clicher’ meaning to click and signifying a stereotype block (stereotype’s etymology is similarly grounded in the printing press). If a printer had a particular phrase that they knew they’d have to use over and over again, they’d often keep have a set block with those words on it. The word cliché was chosen for otomotopaeic reasons, to echo the sound of a mold from a printing press striking metal--although ‘click’ has its own associations now, of course. Even "type," that literary phrase to describe someone whose character is more general and indicative of a class of persons than individuated, appears to be etymologically related to the process of technologically reproducing language via printing. These phrases are early examples of linguistic memes: viral idioms with a disposition that inclines them towards replication, mutation, and dissemination through the mental gene pool.</p> <figure> <img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/cliche.png" alt="Generated with Midjourney with prompt: 'echo the sound of a mold from a printing press striking metal, cliche, in the style of paul klee'."> <figcaption>Generated with Midjourney with prompt: 'echo the sound of a mold from a printing press striking metal, cliche, in the style of paul klee'.</figcaption> </figure><p>By "heterogeneric" I mean more than a text which features multiple <<define "genre" "genres">>. For a text to be heterogeneric in the way I mean, it must knowingly participate--and, in its participation, comment on--in multiple genres over the course of its corpus. Although this knowing commentary is traditionally associated with mashup culture, sampling, and the <<define "multimedial">> remix-first world of social media platforms like Tiktok, it has a much longer lineage.</p> <p> <i>Moby-Dick</i>, the modernist novel <i>par excellance</i>, is heterogeneous to the extreme, which each section--and sometimes each chapter--self-consciously mimicking, parodying, and engaging with different genera, from natural history to Shakespearean drama.</p> <p>Indeed, contemporary reviews of <i>Moby-Dick</i> often commented, more or less favorably, on this radical admixture. One of the most stinging contemporary reviews of <i>Moby-Dick</i>, published in the London Athenaeum, called the novel:</p> <blockquote>an ill-compounded mixture of romance and matter-of-fact... the idea of a connected and collected story has obviously visited and abandoned its writer again and again.</blockquote> <p>Reviewers agreed that Melville’s magnum opus is neither “merely” a sea adventure nor an encyclopedia of information about spermaceti whales but instead a text that partakes in a variety of genres, like a “chowder” (New York Literary World) or, a “salmagundi of fact, fiction, and philosophy”<<cite "33, 53" "Hershel Parker, Moby-Dick as Doubloon: Essays and Extracts">>.</p> <p>Even further back, a novel like <i>Tom Jones</i>, with its flights into mock epic and its satirical eye towards the novels of Samuel Richardson in particular, self-consciously deploys the tropes and trappings of multiple genres. This heterogeneric quality, characteristic of the novel as a form, has significant <<define "epistemological" "genre and epistemology">> implications.</p><p>I’m thinking, here, of gestures--and stylizations of the body more broadly--as encoded and embodied bundles of information in relation to the theory of performativity primarily explored in Butler’s <i>Gender Trouble</i> and <i>Bodies That Matter</i>. I will refer to this in places throughout this document as "informativity".</p> <p>For Butler, the subject is constituted by their performative acts, the platform of which is the body. Butler’s primary focus in "Performative Acts and Gender Constitution: An Essay in Phenomenology and Feminist Theory" (published originally in <i>Theater Journal</i>) is the way gender is constituted through iterated performative acts. With the phenomenological theory of ‘acts’ as a jumping off point, which "seeks to explain the mundane way in which social agents constitute social reality through language, gesture, and all manner of symbolic social sign" <<cite "519" "Butler, Judith. 'Performative Acts and Gender Constitution.'">> Butler discusses the way in which the body works as an “historical idea” and “a set of possibilities to be continually realized.” Consequently, the body is a materializing of possibilities that one “does” (although it’s a mistake to locate agency in the doer of the body, as she clarifies. Gender thus is a “corporeal style” <<cite "522" "Butler, Judith. 'Performative Acts and Gender Constitution.'">> a mode of performing repeated, stylized acts which “compels the body to conform to an historical idea of ‘woman’” and to “induce the body to become a cultural sign” as a “sustained and repeated corporeal project” <<cite "522" "Butler, Judith. 'Performative Acts and Gender Constitution.'">>.</p> <p>Butler’s argument is compelling, but I’d like to push back against the primacy of the body as the organ and the site of these performative acts. The goal of this study, then, is to relocate Butler’s theoretical achievements – in which the world is a stage on which subjects “construct the social fiction of their own psychological interiority” <<cite "528" "Butler, Judith. 'Performative Acts and Gender Constitution.'">> – to some of the new virtual worlds that have opened themselves up with the advent of the information age. As we migrate to new worlds – become "amphibious,"" as Kurt Vonnegut put it in the short story <i>Unready to Wear</i> – it makes less and less sense, I argue, to privilege the material body as the instrument with which one plays oneself. Further, the disjunct between one’s online persona and one’s material body – and the degree of choice one has in crafting an online persona – suggests certain hopeful possibilities insofar as agency is concerned. The inseparable nature of the relationship between the body and the mind (if my reader will forgive a strategic use of the classic Cartesian division) invalidates the premise of a subject who exists prior to the performative acts which constitute them as a subject, but the embodied mind of the “player” behind the computer who controls their persona –does- exist prior to the stylization of that persona. </p> <p>The question running through this dissertation is thus: how does this decentered notion of the subject change once the stage on which identity is performed is untethered from a body which always ‘speaks’ itself? Consequently, I will focus on new ways in which the subject is embodied. If we are willing to accept the premise of ‘social reality,’ we oughtn’t privilege social reality grounded in materiality (or, at least, it can be a useful exercise to deprivilege that social reality in favor of the new virtual worlds offered to us through our computers, our iDevices, and so on). Haraway gestures in this direction in her <i>Cyborg Manifesto</i>, naming “the boundary between physical and nonphysical” as “very imprecise” in the age of technology (589) and discussing the body as a text which can be recoded and rewritten. My premise is that virtual worlds change the way gender narrowly and identity broadly is constituted in social reality, and that the constitution of these new stages has implications for the fate of the subject in the information age. A secondary question is the shifting place of agency and subjectivity more broadly: given that the “player” –does- actually preexist the persona, is the relationship between the two different than that between the mind and the body in a Butlerian schema? </p> <p>The argument in its broadest terms, then, is that the insistence on the body as the instrument and the canvas on which performative acts are inscribed is no longer germane – or, at least, that <<define "virtual worlds" "Cyberspace">> offer new, radically different modes of embodiment--and that the information revolution has provided new stages on which subjects can constitute themselves.</p>In American copyright law, fair use is a legal doctrine that "<a target="_blank" href="assets/pdfs/fairuse.pdf"> promotes freedom of expression by permitting the unlicensed use of copyright-protected works in certain circumstances.</a> [[Section 107 of the Copyright Act]] provides the statuatory framework for determining whether something is a fair use and identifies certain types of uses--such as <b>criticism</b>, comment, news reporting, <b>teaching</b>, <b>scholarship</b>, and <b>research</b>--as examples of activities that may qualify as fair use." To evaluate a question of fair use, there are four legal factors and one practical one: 1) <i>Purpose and character of the use, including whether the use is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes.</i>; 2) <i>The nature of the copyrighted work</i>; 3) <i>The amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the copyrighted work as a whole</i>--a question which often turns on whether or not the "heart" of the work is used; and 4) <i>The effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work</i>. Pragmatically, however, fair use is governed by a system of norms agreed upon by publishers and lawyers. Entities with the financial resources to hire enough more lawyers generally win these cases. [[Information should be free.]]<p>In the context of librarianship, "Information should be free" is a rallying cry against the commodification of information and the privatization of public information. In the context of the internet and the digital humanities, it is a rallying cry against the privatization of cultural heritage and the digital divide. In the context of the contemporary moment, it is a rallying cry against the manipulation of information and the pernicious effects of datafication.</p> <p>The Wikipedia article on the history of the phrase tells the story of the slogan's birth:</p> <blockquote> The phrase "Information wants to be free" was popularized by Stewart Brand during the hacker culture and information revolution of the 1980s and 1990s. Brand was quoted as saying in 1984, "On the one hand information wants to be expensive, because it's so valuable. The right information in the right place just changes your life. On the other hand, information wants to be free, because the cost of getting it out is getting lower and lower all the time. So you have these two fighting against each other." <<cite "4" "Wikipedia">></blockquote> <p>The phrase has been re-popularized in the internet age for its resonance with the promises of the open web. That said, the phrase's original connotations, rooted in hacker culture and the information revolution, are not entirely positive. Brand's position gestured towards the promise of liberation and empowerment that the new wave of computerization held out--but also towards the logistical problem it posed. If information can be seen as a thing, and things have prices, then how is it possible to reconcile the competing impulses of free information and commercialization?</p> <p>The phrase has since been appropriated by librarians and activists working to create a more just and equitable information environment. In January 2012, the Digital Public Library of America launched with a "Declaration of Rights and Responsibilities" that included a version of the phrase:</p> <blockquote>The mission of the DPLA is to expand access to the world's cultural and scientific heritage through collaboration with libraries, institutions, and the general public. We believe that this mission is based on fundamental rights of free expression, privacy, and access to information and that it is carried out through a commitment to excellence in management and stewardship of digital resources. <<cite "13" "Digital Public Library of America">></blockquote> <p>The DPLA's stance echoes the library profession's long-standing commitment to the <<define "Free Library Movement" "Free Library Movement">>, which began in mid-19th century England and eventually spread to the United States, where it gained momentum with the help of philanthropists such as [[Andrew Carnegie]].</p> <p>In the context of the digital humanities, the phrase has been taken up by the [[Open Access movement->Open Access]] and its proponents. According to the Open Access website, "Open Access is a set of principles and a range of practices through which research outputs are distributed online, free of cost or other barriers, and, in its most precise meaning, with the addition of an open license applied to promote reuse." <<cite "14" "Open Access">></p> <p>Open Access's intersection with information wanting to be free is clear. Information, as the DPLA puts it, is a "fundamental right." As such, the move to make it more accessible is a matter of justice, not philanthropy. In this way, information wanting to be free is also a rallying cry against the digital divide. That is, it is a rallying cry for equality of access to information, for the internet to be seen as a public utility, and for the the internet's basic infrastructure to be supported by and responsible to the communities it serves. In this way, information wanting to be free is also a rallying cry against the manipulation of information. That is, it is a rallying cry for the right of individuals to control their own information, for the right of individuals to control their own lives, and for the right of individuals to have access to the tools they need to do that.</p><p>"Hyperhistory" is a conceptual framework proposed by Luciano Floridi that extends the traditional notion of history by encompassing both the tangible historical record and the vast digital landscape of information. Floridi, a philosopher of information, introduces this term to emphasize the interconnectedness of historical narratives and the digital data age.</p> <p>In hyperhistory, historical understanding transcends linear chronology and delves into the dynamic relationships between historical events, people, cultures, and ideas. This framework recognizes the intricate web of information available through digital archives, databases, and online repositories. These digital resources enable the exploration of historical narratives from multiple perspectives and facilitate the analysis of patterns, trends, and connections that might otherwise remain hidden in traditional historical accounts.</p> <p>Hyperhistory underscores the role of technology in reshaping historical research and interpretation. Researchers can now access an unprecedented volume of primary and secondary sources online, enabling the synthesis of diverse viewpoints and the discovery of previously unrecognized correlations. However, this vast sea of digital information also raises challenges related to authenticity, credibility, and the potential for bias in digital historical records.</p> <p>Floridi's concept of hyperhistory invites scholars to critically engage with the evolving nature of historical inquiry in the digital age. It encourages a multidisciplinary approach that merges traditional historical methods with computational techniques, data analysis, and digital tools. By navigating the complexities of hyperhistory, historians and researchers can navigate the intricacies of human history with a broader, more interconnected perspective.</p> <p>Ultimately, hyperhistory acknowledges the transformative power of digital technologies in shaping how we study, interpret, and narrate the past. It calls for a nuanced understanding of historical narratives that not only reflect linear progression but also embrace the complexity and interdependence of information in the digital era.</p><p>The "Information Age" refers to the contemporary era characterized by the widespread accessibility, generation, and exchange of digital information. Emerging from the technological advancements of the late 20th century, particularly in computing and telecommunications, this era marks a pivotal shift in the way societies interact, communicate, and process knowledge.</p> <p>During the Information Age, technological innovations have revolutionized the methods of collecting, storing, and disseminating information. The development of the Internet, a global network of interconnected computers, serves as a cornerstone of this age, enabling instantaneous communication and the rapid sharing of data across vast distances. The proliferation of personal computers, mobile devices, and digital technologies has democratized access to information, transforming the way individuals learn, work, and engage with the world.</p> <p>One of the defining features of the Information Age is the exponential growth of digital data. The creation of vast amounts of information through online interactions, social media, digital commerce, scientific research, and more has led to the concept of "big data." Analyzing and harnessing this data has given rise to data science, machine learning, and artificial intelligence, driving advancements in fields as diverse as healthcare, finance, entertainment, and transportation.</p> <p>The Information Age has also brought about significant societal changes. The rapid dissemination of information has led to increased global connectivity and awareness, shaping public discourse and political landscapes. Online platforms have empowered individuals to voice their opinions, share their stories, and mobilize for social change, leading to both positive movements and challenges in navigating the spread of misinformation and online polarization.</p> <p>Economic landscapes have shifted as well, with the rise of digital economies, e-commerce, and remote work opportunities. Traditional industries have been transformed, and new business models have emerged as technology continues to reshape industries and markets.</p> <p>As the Information Age unfolds, it prompts ongoing discussions about privacy, data security, digital literacy, and the ethical implications of technology. Navigating the complexities of this era requires a balance between embracing the benefits of digital connectivity and critically assessing its potential risks and consequences.</p> <p>In summary, the Information Age represents a pivotal period in human history, characterized by the ubiquity of digital technology and the profound impact it has on communication, knowledge dissemination, societal dynamics, and the very fabric of daily life.</p><p>This study's treatment of nostalgia is grounded in the OED's second definition of the term as a:</p> <blockquote>Sentimental longing for or regretful memory of a period of the past, esp. one in an individual's own lifetime; (also) sentimental imagining or evocation of a period of the past <<cite "*" "Oxford English Dictionary">>.</blockquote> <p>Etymologically, the term comes from the ancient Greek "νόστος", meaning "return home", and <i>αλγία</i>, denoting pain. Literally, then, nostalgia is the pain from homecoming.</p> <p>Less literally, nostalgia is intimately tied to <<define "loss">>, the human impulse to view the past as rosier than the present. For <<define "media" "medium">>, this can present as a fond preference for the technologies of one's youth--hence the rise of vinyl and, later, of cassete tapes among nostalgic audiophiles.</p> <p>Some media forms are nostalgic by nature; for example, photography, in Susan Sontag's telling, is both "a reminder of death" and an "invitation to sentimentality" that turns "the past into an object of tender regard" <<cite "71" "Sontag, Susan. On Photography.">>.</p> <p>The nostalgic impulse is considerably more harmful in the political realm, where it often takes the form of a retrograde privileging of a counterfactual version of history and, in a move which is by definition conservative, seeks a return to that earlier time.</p><p>"Speech Act Theory," pioneered by J.L. Austin and further developed by subsequent scholars, explores the intricate dynamics of language beyond its mere propositional content. This theory delves into the idea that when individuals communicate, they not only convey information but also perform various actions, referred to as "speech acts," that have social, pragmatic, and often transformative implications.</p> <p>J.L. Austin's groundbreaking work in the mid-20th century challenged the traditional understanding of language as a tool primarily for describing reality. Instead, he highlighted the performative nature of language, wherein <<define "utterances" "utterance">> can serve as acts that influence the world and the interactions between individuals. Austin classified speech acts into three categories:</p> <ol> <li><strong>Locutionary Acts:</strong> The basic act of producing sounds or words with syntactic and semantic meaning.</li> <li><strong>Illocutionary Acts:</strong> The intended function or purpose of an utterance, such as making a request, giving a command, offering an apology, or asking a question.</li> <li><strong>Perlocutionary Acts:</strong> The effect of an utterance on the listener or recipient, such as convincing, persuading, amusing, or confusing.</li> </ol> <p>Austin's work laid the foundation for later scholars, notably John Searle, to expand and formalize the theory. Searle introduced the concept of "speech act felicity conditions," which are the contextual prerequisites that determine the success or failure of a speech act. For instance, certain conditions must be met for an utterance to be considered a valid promise or request, including the appropriate context and the speaker's sincerity.</p> <p>Speech Act Theory has wide-ranging implications across various disciplines, including linguistics, philosophy, sociology, and communication studies. It offers insights into how language shapes social realities, the power dynamics embedded in communication, and the role of intention and context in understanding speech. Additionally, the theory contributes to the analysis of politeness, indirect speech, and the nuances of interpersonal communication.</p> <p>Through its exploration of the diverse functions of language, Speech Act Theory highlights the richness and complexity of human communication, revealing that language is not only a tool for conveying information but a means of performing actions, shaping relationships, and co-constructing meaning in the social world.</p><p>I use here what Jim Siemon calls the Bakhtin circle's "radically inclusive notion of 'utterance' as "the minimum to which one can respond, with which one can agree or disagree" <<cite "2" "Siemon, Jim. Word Against Word.">>. An utterance under this sign is thus a subset of gestures, and the totality of these social broadcasts give rise to the performative self.</p><h1><a target="_blank" href="https://opensource.org/licenses/ISC">ISC License</a></h1> <p>Copyright \<YEAR\>, \<OWNER\></p> <p>Permission to use, copy, modify, and/or distribute this software for any purpose with or without fee is hereby granted, provided that the above copyright notice and this permission notice appear in all copies.</p> <p>THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS" AND THE AUTHOR DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES WITH REGARD TO THIS SOFTWARE INCLUDING ALL IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHOR BE LIABLE FOR ANY SPECIAL, DIRECT, INDIRECT, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES OR ANY DAMAGES WHATSOEVER RESULTING FROM LOSS OF USE, DATA OR PROFITS, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, NEGLIGENCE OR OTHER TORTIOUS ACTION, ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE USE OR PERFORMANCE OF THIS SOFTWARE.</p><p>"Y2K," short for "Year 2000," refers to the global technological concern that emerged as the 20th century drew to a close. The Y2K issue was rooted in the way computer systems and software represented years using two-digit date formats (e.g., "99" for 1999). As the year 2000 approached, there was widespread apprehension that these systems would interpret "00" as the year 1900 instead of 2000, potentially causing significant malfunctions, errors, and disruptions across various sectors.</p> <p>Y2K garnered extensive attention due to the reliance of numerous critical systems, including financial institutions, utilities, transportation networks, and government agencies, on computer technology. Concerns included the potential for incorrect calculations, malfunctioning embedded systems, and data corruption, all of which could have far-reaching consequences for both daily life and global infrastructure.</p> <p>In response, governments, businesses, and organizations embarked on comprehensive Y2K readiness efforts, often referred to as "Y2K remediation." This involved identifying vulnerable systems, updating software, rewriting code, and conducting rigorous testing to ensure that computer systems could accurately handle the year 2000 transition. The scale of these preparations was significant, involving extensive collaboration among experts in various fields.</p> <p>As the new millennium arrived, the Y2K issue turned out to be less catastrophic than initially feared. Due to the concerted efforts of countless professionals, the majority of critical systems successfully made the transition to the year 2000 without major disruptions. However, the Y2K challenge highlighted the potential vulnerabilities of technology and underscored the importance of diligent planning, cooperation, and proactive problem-solving in the face of complex, large-scale technical issues.</p> <p>Y2K serves as a historical example of the intersection between technology, public awareness, and global preparedness. The lessons learned from the Y2K experience continue to inform discussions about the resilience of digital infrastructure, the challenges of managing complex systems, and the necessity of anticipating and addressing potential risks in the digital age.</p><p>When we refer here to a "virus", the reader should be aware of the term's computational, cognitive, and biological valences. As expounded in the Blue Kettle case study, all three classes of viruses can be characterized by their essentially replicative character. A [[computational->ILOVEYOU]] virus survives by replicating its code within the host machine's own software; a [[biological->influenza]] virus survives by replicating its own genetic code within the infected body; and a cognitive, or [[memetic->meme]], virus is an idea which, in "going viral" and replicating itself across screens and minds around the world, achieves longevity.</p> <p>The years between 2015 and 2025 may well be called, retroactively, the 'viral' age--years shaped, more than anything, by the world-historical conjunction of the COVID-19 pandemic, the rise of memetic warface in the form of political and ideological disinformation propagated through the internet, and state actors interfering with elections, nuclear programs, utility grids, and more through the dissemination of computer viruses.</p> <img style="max-width:100%" src="assets/imgs/viral_replication_of_a_blue_kettle.png" alt="Generated with Midjourney with prompt: 'glitch, virus, blue kettle, viral replication of a blue kettle, proliferation, glitch art, against a pure black background'.">Virus images here for STUXNET and ILOVEYOU<p>The biologist Richard Dawkins introduced the term "meme" in his 1976 book <i>The Selfish Gene</i>. For him, a meme – from the Greek root <i>mimeme</i>, meaning imitation – is a "replicator" in the "soup of human culture," a "unit of cultural transmission, or a unit of imitation" <<cite "192" "Dawkins, Richard. The Selfish Gene.">>. His examples include "tunes, ideas, catch-phrases, clothes, fashions, ways of making pots or of building arches." A meme-complex, or "memeplex,"" is a collection of these memes that tend to replicate together. Crucially, not all memes are created equal: Dawkins suggests that “longevity, fecundity, and <<define "copying-fidelity" "Loss">> determine how well a unit of culture will replicate and spread through the meme pool <<cite "192" "Dawkins, Richard. The Selfish Gene">>. For many memeticists, these phrases and ideas both parasitize the mind and form it; as Daniel Dennett puts it in his 1991 book <i>Consciousness Explained</i>, “the haven all memes depend on reaching is the human mind, but a human mind is itself an artifact created when memes restructure a human brain in order to make it a better habitat for memes” <<cite "207" "Dennett, Daniel. Consciousness Explained.">> In other words, the meme perspective articulates a reflexive relationship between <<define "information" "Information">>-as-content and consciousness-as-form; individuals arise out of the collection of memes in their minds.</p> <p>The term is commonly (and often interchangeably) used alongside <<define "viral" "Virus">> to describe units of information that spread from person to person across the Internet. Limor Shifman argues that the meme is the "best concept to encapsulate some of the most fundamental aspects of the Internet," providing a vocabulary to examine the “gradual propagation from individuals to society, reproduction via copying and imitation, and diffusion through selection and competition” that units of culture undergo <<cite "18" "Shifman, Limor. Memes in Digital Culture.">>. This approaches the way that ‘meme’ gets used online: as a way of describing the cultural flotsam of the Internet.</p> <p>Michele Knobel and Colin Lankshear gloss this vernacular use of the term meme, which better describes the particular way in which memes operate online, "to describe the rapid uptake and spread of a 'particular idea presented as a written text, image, <<define "language 'move'" "Language Game">>, or some other unit of cultural stuff” <<cite "202" "Lankshear, Colin, and Michele Knobel. New Literacies.">>. The way that the meaning of the word meme has mutated, from Dawkins’ definition to this vernacular use, has been taken by Dawkins and others to be indicative of the way that memes themselves function; in a speech given at the Cannes Film Festival, Dawkins announced that "the very idea of the meme has itself mutated and evolved in a new direction. An Internet meme is a hijacking of the original idea. Instead of mutating by random chance […] Internet memes are altered deliberately by human activity. In some cases, this can take the form of genuinely creative art" <<cite "4:08" "Dawkins, Richard. Just for Hits.">>. Although this distinction is a helpful one, it elides the fact that many Internet memes are mutated not by humans but instead by <<define "computers" "AI">>, or by a collaboration between humans and machines. Still, the difference between a meme in the classic sense and an Internet meme is not as great as it might seem; indeed, the latter is primarily a subset of the former, and drawing a hard distinction between memes with digital material supports and memes with analogue supports is only helpful inasmuch as the difference between the two is instructive.</p> For some examples of memes, see the <<excerpt "Meme Gallery">>.<p>"Influenza," commonly known as the flu, is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It is characterized by a range of symptoms that can vary in severity, from mild to severe, and can lead to complications, especially in vulnerable populations. The flu viruses are classified into different types and subtypes, including influenza A, B, and C, based on their genetic makeup.</p> <p>Flu symptoms typically include fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, body aches, fatigue, and headaches. In some cases, individuals may experience vomiting and diarrhea, although these symptoms are more common in children. The flu is often confused with the common cold due to the similarity of symptoms, but the flu tends to be more intense and may lead to more severe health outcomes.</p> <p>Each year, seasonal flu outbreaks occur, primarily during the fall and winter months. The flu can spread through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, as well as through contact with contaminated surfaces. Because the influenza virus can mutate and change over time, new strains can emerge, which is why flu vaccines are updated annually to match the most prevalent strains expected for the upcoming flu season.</p> <p>Flu vaccination is a key preventive measure recommended by health authorities worldwide. The flu vaccine helps reduce the risk of infection and, even if an individual still contracts the flu, vaccination can often lead to milder symptoms and reduced risk of complications. Vaccination is especially important for certain groups, such as the elderly, young children, pregnant women, and individuals with underlying health conditions, who are at higher risk of severe flu-related complications.</p> <p>While most people recover from the flu without any long-term effects, complications can arise, particularly in vulnerable individuals. These complications may include pneumonia, bronchitis, sinus and ear infections, and worsening of pre-existing medical conditions. Therefore, seeking medical attention and following recommended treatments is important, especially for those at higher risk.</p> <p>In summary, influenza is a viral respiratory illness that can lead to a range of symptoms, with the potential for severe complications, particularly in certain populations. Annual flu vaccination, along with good hygiene practices, such as regular handwashing and covering coughs and sneezes, are essential strategies for reducing the spread of the flu and minimizing its impact on public health.</p><p>In the interstices of human connection and cybernetic replication lies the curious case of the ILOVEYOU computer worm, also known colloquially as the Love Bug. Crafted by Onel de Guzman, a student in Manila, this worm began its digital promenade on May 4, 2000, insinuating itself into the world’s digital corridors via email with an enticing subject line: "ILOVEYOU". Despite its seemingly innocuous invitation, the file attached carried a script that, once executed, would overwrite crucial data and replicate itself across the infected system's network via Microsoft Outlook's address book.</p> <p>De Guzman’s creation exploited the socio-technical vulnerabilities inherent in early internet culture—chief among them, the human propensity for curiosity and connection. The worm’s spread was undergirded by a script that capitalized on a default Windows setting hiding file extensions, thus masking its malicious intent behind the guise of a benign text file <<cite "1" "ILOVEYOU--Wikipedia">>. The resulting chaos highlighted the fragile interdependencies of global networks, precipitating a cascade of shutdowns in critical infrastructures such as the Pentagon and the British Parliament.</p> <p>This incident not only triggered a reevaluation of cyber security protocols but also spurred legislative shifts, notably in the Philippines, where the lack of laws against malware production had initially stymied prosecutorial efforts. The ILOVEYOU worm thus stands as a stark embodiment of the tensions between connectivity’s promises and its perils, a digital organism whose replication mechanics reflect both the technical vectors that enable data transmission and the human gestures that propel their spread.</p> <p>The event's cultural echoes reverberate in discussions about internet safety, the ethics of software creation, and the broader implications of our intertwined digital lives. As a literary figure, ILOVEYOU transmutes from a mere technical anomaly into a symbol of our collective vulnerability to the siren calls of digital intimacy and the shadowed costs of open networks.</p><p>While this document was being written, COVID-19 happened (and continues to happen). It is difficult to overestimate the degree to which the virus changed the global landscape, and outside the scope of a document like this; that said, it is worth remarking upon that many of the thought experiments originally posited here, particularly in the introduction, went from outlandish to anodyne as a result. For example, positing a United States of America where more of the social gestures that people perform took place on digital platforms than in person was difficult for folks of a certain age to imagine in, say, 2018; now, six years later, those of us whose memories still work can recall the lived experience of taking classes and meetings and social calls and awkard movie nights on Zoom, with all of the attendant gains and losses thereof.</p> <p>As of this writing (April 28, 2024), the World Health Organization estimates that 7,045,569 people have died, globally, from COVID-19. <<cite "1" "WHO COVID-19 Dashboard">></p>More to be written here.<p>Walter Benjamin's concept of "aura" describes the unique, unapproachable quality of an authentic work of art, rooted in its presence in time and space, and inextricably linked to its history and context. This aura embodies the work’s originality and its ritualistic value, which, according to Benjamin, are fundamentally compromised by mechanical reproduction techniques such as photography and film. As these technologies proliferate, the aura diminishes, detaching the art from its unique existence and allowing it to be encountered in myriad, often trivial, contexts. Benjamin posits that this shift not only transforms the function of art—from ritual to exhibition—but also reflects broader social changes in how we perceive and value cultural artifacts in a reproducible, commodified form <<cite "4" "Benjamin, Walter. 'The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction'.">>.</p> <p>This concept ties directly into the dissertation's exploration of authenticity, representation, and the impact of digital reproduction on human perception and knowledge. Just as Benjamin critiques how reproduction erodes the aura of art, the dissertation argues that the digital landscape—through algorithms, databases, and AI—creates a similar erosion in our understanding of texts and narratives. In both cases, the commodification of content leads to a loss of depth and singularity, mirroring the broader theme of alienation within a technologically mediated world. By juxtaposing Benjamin's concerns with the contemporary digital context, the dissertation underscores the ongoing relevance of his insights in a new, digitally saturated era.</p>Per <a target="_blank" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_frame">Wikipedia</a>, a key frame (or keyframe) in animation and filmmaking is "a drawing or shot that defines the starting and ending points of any smooth transition. These are called frames because their position in time is measured in frames on a strip of film or on a digital video editing timeline. A sequence of key frames defines which movement the viewer will see, whereas the position of the key frames on the film, video, or animation defines the timing of the movement. Because only two or three key frames over the span of a second do not create the illusion of movement, the remaining frames are filled with 'inbetweens'" For animation, a keyframe can be thought of like a single snapshot of a stop-motion animation. Each keyframe is (generally) manually posed. This works differently than animation which leverages <<define "motion-capture data" "Motion-capture data">> to transcode captured <<define "meatspace" "Meatspace">> gestures into data that can be used to animate a model.<p>Thought experiments are hypothetical situations that allow us to explore what would happen if a particular principle were true, or a particular thing were the case. They are useful in philosophy and science, because they allow us to explore the implications of a particular idea without having to actually go through the process of making that idea a reality.</p> <p>Some common thought experiments in philosophy include the <<define "Chinese Room Argument">>, which was used by John Searle to show that computers cannot be said to understand language, and the <<define "Trolley Problem">>, which is used to explore the implications of different ethical theories.</p> <p>Daniel Dennett's term "intuition pump" is closely related to the thought experiment; an intuition pump is a thought experiment that is designed to help us understand a particular concept by providing a concrete example of it. Intuition pumps are often used in philosophy and cognitive science to help us understand complex concepts like consciousness and free will. For more on intuition pumps, see Daniel Dennett's book <i>Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking</i>. </p><p>The Chinese Room Argument is a thought experiment that was first proposed by John Searle in 1980. It is designed to show that computers cannot be said to understand language. The argument goes as follows:</p> <blockquote>Suppose that I am locked in a room, and that I am given a set of rules in English that tell me how to respond to questions in Chinese. I do not understand Chinese, but I can follow the rules, and so I can give correct answers to questions in Chinese. Now, suppose that someone outside the room asks me a question in Chinese. I look up the rules, and I give them a correct answer. But do I understand Chinese? No, I do not. I am just following rules. Similarly, computers do not understand language, they just follow rules. Therefore, computers cannot be said to understand language.</blockquote><p>The Trolley Problem is a thought experiment that is used to explore the implications of different ethical theories. The problem goes as follows:</p> <blockquote>You are driving a trolley, and you see that there are five people in the path of the trolley. You can either do nothing, and the trolley will kill the five people, or you can pull a lever, and the trolley will switch to a different track, killing one person. What should you do?</blockquote> <p>The trolley problem is often used to show that utilitarianism is the correct ethical theory. According to utilitarianism, the right thing to do is the thing that will produce the greatest amount of happiness for the greatest number of people. In this case, the right thing to do is to pull the lever, because it will produce more happiness overall. However, there are many different ways of interpreting the trolley problem, and it is not clear that it shows that utilitarianism is the correct theory. For more on the trolley problem, see Peter Singer's book <i>Practical Ethics</i>.</p><p>The <<excerpt "Euthyphro Dilemma">> is a thought experiment that was first proposed by Socrates. It is designed to show that the traditional conception of piety is false. The problem goes as follows:</p> <p>Euthyphro is a man who has been charged with impiety, and he is trying to defend himself. Socrates asks him to define piety, and Euthyphro says that it is "the doing of what is dear to the gods." Socrates then asks whether the gods love what is pious because it is pious, or whether it is pious because the gods love it. Euthyphro cannot give a satisfactory answer to this question, and so Socrates concludes that the traditional conception of piety is false. For more on the Euthyphro Dilemma, see Plato's dialogue <i>Euthyphro</i>. </p><p>John McQuarrie and Edward Robinson's translation of Martin Heideggers <i>Being and Time</i> contains a glossary of German Expressions which glosses <i>zuhanden</i> and <i>Zuhandenheit</i> as "ready-to-hand" and "readiness-to-hand", respectively <<cite "520" "Heidegger, Martin. Being and Time.">>. This term is contrasted with <i>vorhanden</i> and <i>Vorhandenheit</i>, or "present-at-hand" and "presence-at-hand" <<cite "518" "Heidegger, Martin. Being and Time.">>. Where the ready-to-hand describes our "practical relationship to things that are handy or useful", the present-at-hand instead describes "our theoretical apprehension of a world made up of objects" <<cite "*" "Critchley, Simon. 'Being and Time, part 3: Being-in-the-world.'">>. Crucially, for Heidegger the zuhanden precedes the vorhanden; that is, practice precedes theory, and our initial apprehension of objects in the world is ordinarily and fundamentally oriented towards what those objects do and can be used for.</p> <p>What fascinates me is the relationship between zuhanden and vorhanden, and the way that a broken tool, a piece of equipment poorly suited for its purpose, announces its own presence as a result of its inutility. In Heidegger's words:</p> <blockquote> When we concern ourselves with something, the entities which are most closely ready-to-hand may be met as something unusable, not properly adapted for the use we have decided upon. The tool turns out to be damaged, or the material unsuitable. In each of these cases <i>equipment</i> is here, ready-to-hand. We discover its unusability, however, not by looking at it and establishing its properties, but rather by the circumspection of the dealings in which we use it. When its unusability is thus discovered, equipment becomes conspicuous. This <i>conspicuousness</i> presents the ready-to-hand equipment as in a certain un-readiness-to-hand. But this implies that what cannot be used just lies there; it shows itself as an equipmental Thing which looks so and so, and which, in its readiness-to-hand as looking that way, has constantly been present-at-hand too. Pure presence-at-hand announces itself in such equipment, but only to withdraw to the readiness-to-hand of something with which one concerns oneself--that is to say, of the sort of thing we find when we put it back into repair.<br> [...]<br> Similarly, when something ready-to-hand is found missing, though its everyday presence [<i>zugegensein</i>] has been so obvious that we have never taken any notice of it, this makes a <i>break</i> in those referential contexts which circumspection discovers. Our circumspection comes up against emptiness, and now sees for the first time <i>what</i> the missing article was ready-to-hand <i>with</i>, and <i>what</i> it was ready-to-hand <i>for</i>. The environment announces itself afresh<<cite "103" "105" "Heidegger, Martin. Being and Time.">>. </blockquote> <p>In other words, there is a character to a thing which announces itself only when the usefulness of that thing breaks down. This is particularly germane in the case of the <<define "cyborg">>, where biological and technological comes together to create a hybridized being. In the case of an <<define "inforg" "Inforg">> with an <<define "extended mind" "the extended mind">>, for example, it is only when the technological <<define "prosthetic" "Prosthetic">> breaks down--when, for example, the battery of the cell phone serving as my prosthetic memory runs out--that "pure presence-at-hand announces itself," the phone becomes <i>vorhanden</i> rather than <i>zuhanden</i>, and my own cyborg mode of being becomes conspicuous.</p><p>The Narrative Self is a concept that views personal identity as constructed through the stories we tell about ourselves. Rather than being a fixed entity, the self is continually shaped and reshaped by the narratives that we create and reinterpret over time. This idea aligns with the theories of narrative psychology, which suggest that the self is fundamentally a narrative construct—a story woven from past experiences, aspirations, relationships, and cultural context. The Narrative Self is inherently fluid and fragmented, reflecting the ongoing process of meaning-making that is central to human cognition and experience.</p> <p>This concept connects closely with the dissertation's examination of identity in a digital age, where the self is often represented and mediated through algorithms, social media, and other technologies that continuously rewrite our personal narratives. As the dissertation argues, the Narrative Self becomes increasingly complex in the context of digital surveillance and datafication, where external forces influence the stories we construct about ourselves, often without our awareness or consent. This highlights the tensions between personal agency and technological determinism, echoing broader themes of authenticity, representation, and control within contemporary digital culture.</p><p>Meatspace is the analog inversion of <<define "cyberspace" "Cyberspace">>: the world of physical "meat suits" (that is, bodies). The term often attributed to William Gibson, who describes the meat/cyber binary in <i>Neuromancer</i> thusly:</p> <p>"For Case, who’d lived for the bodiless exultation of cyberspace, it was the Fall. In the bars he’d frequented as a cowboy hotshot, the elite stance involved a certain relaxed contempt for the flesh. The body was meat. Case fell into the prison of his own flesh." <<cite "6" "Gibson, William. Neuromancer.">></p><p>"Cyberspace" is a now-dated term referring to the online world as the digital inversion of <<define "meatspace" "Meatspace">>. As Lincoln Dahlberg writes in a 1998 article, cyberspace is a "virtual meeting place" that, at that point, was seen as "providing the basis for the revitalisation of the public sphere and democracy"--in other words, a would-be utopian update to Jürgen Habermas's "public sphere" <<cite "1" "Dahlberg, Lincoln. Cyberspace and the Public Sphere: Exploring the Democratic Potential of the Net.">>. Dahlberg's article is prescient inasmuch as it identifies the consolidation of cyberspace under the aegis of capital, in the form of telecommunication and technology companies, as reason to be wary of over-utopian theorizing.</p> <p>Chip Morningstar and F. Randall Farmer's piece in the 2003 <i>New Media Reader</i>, defines cyberspace less in terms of its technological support and more in terms of the "interactions among the actors within it" <<cite "664" "Morningstar, Chip, and Farmer, F. Randall. The Lessons of Lucasfilm's Habitat.">>. In this telling, cyberspace is first and foremost a "many-participant environment" where various sorts of actors come together, converse, and interact.</p> <p>For myself, the term cyberspace brings to mind two platforms where I grew up--<<define "MUDs" "MUD">> and <<define "World of Warcraft">>. I spent hours of every day in these virtual worlds, inhabiting textual and graphical <<define "personae" "Persona">> with bodies radically different from my own and answering to names with no connection to my own. I made friends that I remain in contact with to this day; I was the best man at one such friend's wedding. On many days, I spent more time online than off, and the social behavior with which I gestured myself into being was platformed in this cyberspace.</p> <p>Of course, this was a more radical idea in 2019 than it became in 2020, when many of the knowledge workers who I assume are the audience for this dissertation found themselves living their lives in cyberspace, struggling against the <<define "lossy" "Loss">> constraints of platforms like Zoom.</p><p>A "cyborg," short for "cybernetic organism," is a conceptual entity that merges the realms of <<define "meatspace" "Meatspace">> and <<define "cyberspace" "Cyberspace">>, blurring the boundaries between the physical and digital domains. Coined by Manfred Clynes and Nathan S. Kline in 1960, the term initially referred to the augmentation of human capabilities through technological enhancements, illustrating the potential for humans to transcend their biological limitations. Over time, the concept of a cyborg has evolved beyond mere physical adaptations, encompassing the symbiotic relationship between humans and technology.</p> <p>Cyborgs embody a fusion of organic and artificial components, embodying a spectrum of forms from subtle technological augmentations to more elaborate integrations. Donna Haraway's influential essay "A Cyborg Manifesto" introduced the idea of cyborgs as beings that challenge traditional notions of gender, identity, and embodiment, suggesting that technology can dismantle oppressive social constructs. Haraway's work emphasized the subversion of established norms and the empowerment derived from embracing the hybrid nature of cyborg existence.</p> <p>In contemporary contexts, the term "cyborg" encapsulates individuals who engage with digital environments, such as virtual reality, social media, and wearable technology, to extend their cognitive and communicative abilities. The prevalence of smartphones, smartwatches, and wearable fitness trackers has propelled the integration of technology into daily life, contributing to the normalization of cyborg-like experiences.</p> <p>Cyborgs not only challenge the dichotomy between the physical and the digital but also raise ethical, philosophical, and sociopolitical questions about identity, privacy, agency, and the potential for exploitation by corporations and governments. As technology continues to advance, the notion of what constitutes a cyborg continues to expand, reflecting the evolving relationship between humans and the digital realm.</p> <p>For instance, individuals who use brain-computer interfaces to control external devices or who implant microchips for convenience illustrate the contemporary cyborg sensibility, where the line between human and machine blurs, and the boundaries of self shift in intriguing and sometimes disconcerting ways.</p> <p>In the intricate dance between human and machine, the concept of the cyborg provokes contemplation about the nature of existence, the malleability of identity, and the uncharted territories of a future where the organic and the synthetic intertwine.</p><p>MUD stands for "Multi-User Dungeon" and describes a once-popular genre of multiplayer text-based roleplaying games that preceded massively multiplayer online RPGs like <<define "World of Warcraft">>. They worked a bit like a multiplayer version of early adventure games like Zork; users (often volunteers) wrote room descriptions, monster descriptions, in-world books, and indeed whole worlds, and then wrote characters to explore those worlds.</p> <p>I would estimate that I spent around 3500 hours on MUDs between the age of 15 and 25; I met my first girlfriend on one, through out-of-character chats, and made many friends with whom I remain close. I spent around 1000 hours as Adrian Fripp, a very important druid and one-time king, and on many days spent more time as him than as Ken Alba. Spending that much time as someone else necessarily changes the player; I would not be who I am without the time I spent growing up in this particular kind of world. Without MUDs, many of the questions that have animated my research into performance and identity would never have occurred to me.</p><p>An avatar is a digital representation or embodiment of a user within a virtual environment, such as a video game, social platform, or other interactive digital spaces. This representation can range from simple graphical icons or pictograms to highly detailed and customizable three-dimensional figures, often reflecting aspects of the user’s <<define "identity" "information and selfhood">>, preferences, or aspirations.</p> <p>The concept of the avatar, originating from the Sanskrit "avatāra," meaning the descent of a deity into the earthly realm, signifies the user’s ability to project themselves into a digital space, effectively "descending" into a virtual reality. This process of embodiment allows the user to interact within the environment, engage with other avatars, and navigate the complexities of virtual worlds.</p> <p>Avatars serve not merely as tools of interaction but as extensions of the self, often embodying aspects of the user’s personality or <<define "persona" "Persona">>. In some contexts, the avatar functions as a mask, concealing the user’s true identity, while in others, it reveals and amplifies certain characteristics, allowing for a form of self-expression that might be limited in the physical world.</p><p>A multimedial text is a text which exists on and across multiple platforms. In the era of "Big Marvel," this can be compared to the corporate world's zest for vertical integration, but the term ought to be untethered from capitalism's totalizing yoke and instead connected with texts, like <i>Achewood</i>, which exist online, on paper, in games, and, in short, across multiple <<define "media" "medium">> forms. A multimedial text may or may not be <<define "heterogeneric," "heterogeneric">> but the terms are not equivalent. Although different media forms do lend themselves to different genres, the two terms are distinct inasmuch as 'media' focuses on platform and the materiality of the text--as film, as game, and paper book--and 'genre' focuses on the tropes, dramatic structure, and other distinguishing features of the text.</p><p>Medium, often seen in this study in its plural "media" form, describes the technological substrate on which a given text is transmitted or appears. A text can be <<define "multimedial">>, in which case it appears on multiple media, or it appear via a single medium, like a paper book (although, even in this case, a book's <<define "paratext" "paratexts">> might well cross over into other media.</p> <p>Marshall McLuhan's famous dicta that "the medium is the message" and that a medium can be defined as a "extension of ourselves" gestures towards the co-constituitive relationship that media, <<define "genre">>, and <<define "identity and selfhood" "selfhood">> have in contributing to personal identity in the <<define "information age">>.</p><p>The word “person” has an interesting history. On the one hand, there’s the common understanding of it, which the Oxford English Dictionary lists as the second entry: “an individual human being; a man, woman, or child.” On the other, it stems etymologically from the Latin persona, meaning “mask used by a player, character in a play, dramatic role, the part played by a person in life, character, role, position,” which gives “person” its first entry: “a role taken by a person.” Most intriguing is “person”s sister word, persona, which remains in English and means “the aspect of a person’s character that is displayed to or perceived by others” <<cite "OED" "Oxford English Dictionary">>. These terms suggests two ways of understanding personhood: in one, the subject is constituted by their individuality, their mind, their personality – in a word, their self. In the other, a person is constituted by the way their identity is performed and perceived by other people – a sort of constructed social identity made up by the masks they wear. The former understanding presumes an autonomous subject and an autonomous will in a way predicated on a kind of essentialism; the latter is more in line with the insights provided by the postmodern turn, which has decentered the subject in radical and productive ways.</p> <p>This decentered subject has been the object of critical study for decades now. Judith Butler, in particular, has provided insight into the way a subject is constituted by their iterated <<define "performative acts" "information and selfhood">>, the organ of which is the body. Her argument is compelling, but as we migrate to new, digital worlds, it makes less sense to privilege the <<define "material body" "meatspace">> over the <<define "avatar" "Avatar">> as the instrument with which one plays oneself.</p>"107. Limitations on exclusive rights: Fair use Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 106 and 106A, the fair use of a copyrighted work, including such use by reproduction in copies or phonorecords or by any other means specified by that section, for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching (including multiple copies for classroom use), scholarship, or research, is not an infringement of copyright. In determining whether the use made of a work in any particular case is a fair use the factors to be considered shall include— (1) the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes; (2) the nature of the copyrighted work; (3) the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the copyrighted work as a whole; and (4) the effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work. The fact that a work is unpublished shall not itself bar a finding of fair use if such finding is made upon consideration of all the above factors."The most naive way of expressing the distinction between <<define "data" "Data">> and <<define "information" "Information">> is to rely on Luciano Floridi's definition of information as "meaningful, well-ordered data" <<cite "8" "Floridi, Luciano. Information: A Very Short Introduction.">>. Data here are the raw material out of which instrumentally useful information is made. In other words, as Lisa Gitelman and Virginia Jackson put it in the introduction to <i>'Raw Data' is an Oxymoron</i>, "data are apparently before the fact" <<cite "2" "Gitelman, Lisa. 'Raw Data' is an Oxymoron.">>. Instrumentally, then, we can think about data as 'preprocessed' information that needs to be mined and refined until it's meaningful, like the raw sense data of Kantian cognition that precedes the operations of the imagination and the understanding. Zeroes and ones, serialized dictionaries, and electrical variances become lights on a screen that make words, images, and other <<define "medium">> with meaning; the former is data, the latter information. However, as Gitelman's title suggests, this definition fails to account for the way in which data have to be "imagined <i>as</i> data to exist and function as such, and the imagination of data entails an interpretive base" <<cite "3" "Gitelman, Lisa. 'Raw Data' is an Oxymoron.">>--and, as research and news stories on everything from cameras that can't see people of color to algorithms that re-enact redlining have demonstrated, an interpretive base is awfully close to an interpretive bias. Data cannot be prior to interpretation because its extraction is accomplished by human-made tools that can reflect the biases, blind spots, and bad motives of their engineers. Garbage in, garbage out.<p>The <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span> here is defined as both a technical term and as an aesthetic moment.</p> <p>From a technical perspective, a <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span> is, per the OED:</p> <blockquote>A surge of current or a spurious electrical signal; also, in extended use, a sudden short-lived irregularity in behaviour.<<cite "*" "Oxford English Dictionary">></blockquote> <p>From an aesthetic perspective, however, the <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span> is a moment when less becomes more, when the <<define "lossy" "loss">> contingencies of digital being paradoxically give rise to the production of something novel. This is often accompanied by a shift in the hermeneutic categorization of <<define "signal" "Signal">> and <<define "noise" "Noise">> as discrete; instead, under the sign of the <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span>, the two switch places, intermingle, and become a new signal.</p> <p>In the context of informational performativity, we might think about the <span class="glitch" data-text="glitch">glitch</span> as a mode of resistance to binary oppositions imposed by platforms.</p> <p>See [[Blue Kettle->Case Study: BLUE KETTLE]] and [[Menkman's Glitch Studies Manifesto->Ross Menkman’s 2010 Glitch Studies Manifesto]].</p>"In new media lingo, to 'transcode' something is to translate it into another format. The computerization of culture gradually accomplishes similar transcoding in relation to all cultural categories and concepts. That is, cultural categories and concepts are substituted, on the level of meaning and/or the language, by new ones which derive from computer’s ontology, epistemology and pragmatics. New media thus acts as a forerunner of this more general process of cultural re-conceptualization." <<cite "45" "Manovich, Lev. The Language of New Media.">><p><<define "Data">> takes up space to store and bandwidth to transmit. By utilizing compression algorithms, the amount of space that data takes up can be reduced. However, that compression is seldom a lossless--or reversible--process. Instead, data is ordinarily lost during compression. These compression algorithms undergird the systems by which <<define "medium">> is transmitted online. </p> <p>Loss is not unique to digital transcoding. Consider the process by which a 70mm film is transcoded into a digital format. This process can be 'lossless' inasmuch as it produces an enormous video file that, in theory, could be used to print a new 70mm film.
